instruction: Can you make ASCII art? If so, can you show me a house?
output:
Can you make ASCII art? If so, can you show me a house? How about an ikon? A banner? A sticker? Perhaps, you can help your family, friends or colleagues? A birthday message? There is no end to the things you can do
What makes OOOP! cool?
It's open. Anyone can come and join. Anyone with something to share can share it. You can be as active or as quiet as you please. If you do something you like, more people will know about you (and your work), helping to make your project bigger.
It's collaborative. Everyone can learn from each other; you don't need to know all of the answers. The less you know, the more you can learn. And the more you learn, the more you will enjoy OOOP!.
It's exciting. Lots of things are being done that haven't been done before.
It's social. You can show your friends what you're doing. What's more, you can make friends with other people involved in OOOP!. You might find some people that share your interests, or even want to help you with your work. If you're not one to show off, no problem: you can just work away in peace. (OOOP! isn't a bad place to be quiet, either, so don't worry if you're shy.)
It's professional. This isn't just a bunch of people working on things they'll never do anything with. There are professionals making professional-quality work. It shows what can be done, and helps set the standard. But it's not just work for work's sake: it's not just for games programmers. There are other projects you can contribute to, including those for the less computer-literate - they wouldn't have a project without people like these.
What can you do?
Whatever you like, obviously. You don't need to be good at anything: it's good to learn how to fix bugs or how to code. In fact, you'll probably need to do lots of things you've never done before. It may be great fun though, and you may find people keen to help you. (If you're a beginner, the Community help you can find should set you on the right track.)
But what about...
...the scary programmers?
If you're really not sure how to tackle things but you'd like feedback, you can always put your questions in #ooop on irc.freenode.net. You do not have to use OL. You can also post your questions on the OL forum, (and, of course, you always have the community help) but if you do this, you may not be doing enough research beforehand, and there's no guarantee that someone else won't answer before OL gets to you.
The bigwigs
The bigwigs don't seem to be doing any work at all. They're only interested in management.
If only there was someone who could help you...
There is a small team of core volunteers who are taking major decision-making roles in OL. This does not mean they're not taking an interest in OL; it just means they recognise the scope and importance of their roles.
So what are you?
No, you're not, but there isn't really a good term for members and contributors that is not vague. You could say that you've 'come to OL to help us'. Or that you're helping OL's 'community'. Or maybe you're a 'content contributor' or, to people who don't know anything else about you, one of these 'contributors'.
Why not a 'contributor' then?
In OL, 'contributor' is too loose a word. It's just a generic term that can cover people who just like to answer questions on OL (on or off OL), people who work on bug-fixing or on content creation, people who translate new content. And, a lot of the time, people who have just done something that they consider 'helpful' (a 'bug fix', or even a change to the OL Wiki) - which is why it's a term that's not really useful.
And a 'member'?
Well, this can easily be misunderstood, as it's a misnomer. It's not that people have to join OL...
...well, they don't have to, but they do anyway. And it's possible to be a member of OL in spirit, but not 'legally' or anything. You can 'join' OL to get more access, help things run more smoothly

instruction: What are you thinking of right now?
output: What are you thinking of right now? Where are you?‚Äù For most of us, the answer is pretty simple. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sitting in the dentist‚Äôs office.‚Äù Or ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all I did this morning: open my computer to see how much traffic I have, check my e-mail, get something on the Web . . .‚Äù The world becomes the narrow confines of our desk. How can we break out of that state of mind? To begin, we must create our own space from your desk. When doing work that you detest, it‚Äôs all too easy to get carried away in front of the computer and not break from it for long periods of time. You begin to see yourself as that person who can do nothing but work, not even go to the bathroom, talk to someone else, read the paper, or take a walk around the office or block. But if you become that person long enough, you‚Äôll notice that you‚Äôve got a serious habit on your hands. Your ability to create a space that is yours will become more pronounced as you go along. As you grow stronger in this habit, you can also bring it into areas outside of the office. For example, instead of getting caught up in one task, try creating a space in your mind that is uninhabited so that you can observe it as your own, an independent sphere that is yours alone. You can find this space while doing something else, going for a walk, enjoying a meal with your family, or taking a shower. In his book, The Power of Full Engagement: Managing Energy, Not Time, for High Performance, Jim Loehr and Tony Schwartz offer some great advice for managing your work day: ‚ÄúMake each day more than it is, and make it more than you can handle. If you do, you‚Äôll find that the more each day asks of you, the more you‚Äôll be able to accomplish.‚Äù The way it is often expressed, ‚ÄúAll work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.‚Äù Work is work and play is play, and when you combine the two, the play part gets turned into work or work becomes work so that it becomes less effective. Don‚Äôt become so immersed in your work that you forget to take time to play. Creating your own space and becoming aware of your surroundings are two of many important disciplines you can use to overcome our tendency as humans to get caught up in the day-to-day events of our life. These practices are just as important in our pursuit of wellness. 2. When you are in the midst of an event, practice letting go of control. Our society is all about control, and there are many reasons that we feel so much pressure to control all of ourselves and all of the important things in our lives. If we let go of that need for control, we might not be able to perform some of the activities we had to do. But that is a choice. And the more we know of our own weaknesses and the things that we can‚Äôt control, the more at ease we‚Äôll feel, and the more likely we‚Äôll be to make the most of those situations where we do have a high degree of control. The trick to doing both of the above two disciplines successfully in your life is to find a way of letting go of these things, because it is actually quite difficult to let go of them. We become so used to controlling our lives that we begin to think that having control makes us feel powerful. Let‚Äôs face it. In our business, in our careers, and in our personal lives, we have all the control we will ever have. It‚Äôs there, and it won‚Äôt be gone. What we can never control is the outcome. We can only control our action. If we learn about this, we will spend our time focusing on the things we can do to control the outcomes for ourselves. Instead, we should always focus on what we can do, and use our talents and know-how to get those things done. When something happens that is outside of your control, the first thing you should do is accept it. We must stop thinking about what we can do to change it. It‚Äôs a waste of time. Instead of focusing on what you can‚Äôt do, focus on what you can do. The only way you can really influence the outcome is by influencing your actions. But you can‚Äôt have influence if you have no control. So you must get control of something. Get control of your response. It‚Äôs pretty easy to put on a show, to come up with a great excuse for what happened, or to criticize other people. But if a bad decision has come out of your actions, own up to it. No one would want to hire someone who refuses to be accountable for the decisions he or she makes. And if something is not working, stop doing it. It is OK to let go, to give it up and move on

Can you help me understand how I can estimate the variance of a variable?

A: You cannot.
It would require you to specify whether you can observe the values of the target variable independently, i.e. how different individuals are observed together or not, and whether the predictor variables are fixed or dependent (on some other variable which is not observed)
If you can observe the target variable together with all the predictor variables, you can estimate a variance-covariance matrix, which gives a measure of correlation between the variables. The square root of the determinant of this is your estimated variance.  This assumes that values of the variables are independent. 
You can estimate this, for example, if you have repeated measurements on the same subjects, but with some additional uncertainty in the estimates depending on the precision of your measurement procedure.

instruction: What parts of the human genome describe physical appearance and how can they be reprogrammed using modern methods like crisper? give samples using python code
output:
What parts of the human genome describe physical appearance and how can they be reprogrammed using modern methods like crisper? give samples using python code if possibile

A: There is currently no practical method to change your facial appearance through genetic modification.
Human genome is made of three billion "letters", which can be divided into 23 pairs of chromosomes (there are 22 autosomes which make up the 22 pairs and an XY chromosome pair). The letters are the chemical "base pairs" A, C, T and G. Each chromosome is made up of different amounts of bases so the size of the genome varies from person to person.
The amount of bases in a chromosome is not entirely determined by the gene that it harbours, but can also be determined by regulatory regions such as promoters (often found downstream of the gene being regulated) or enhancers (often found upstream of the gene being regulated). In particular, the DNA sequences that act to silence or activate other genes can be found in these regulatory regions.
The sequence of these bases is translated into amino acids, which are strings of three "letters" (called codons) each with the corresponding amino acid: AAA is Isoleucine, ACT is Threonine, GCG is Valine etc, leading to a large number of combinations, as each amino acid can have up to three different codons (it is slightly more than six if you include stop codons).
Some genes are on the genome for the sole purpose of reading in the DNA so that they can make copies of themselves, or for editing or deleting them based on the DNA they read in, for example, the first gene in chromosome one is the gene that will make copies of itself, and these copies of the gene will make copies of themselves, and so on, up to 21 times. We call it 'initiation' and it is the first gene because it will make the other genes. Another example is a repressor (a transcription factor) which can either help an already-started process, or stop it completely. It is therefore essential to the normal process of reading DNA, and we call it essential as it is essential for the process of reproduction.
There are also genes with no function at all. We call them 'non-coding' and they are also essential genes, but have no actual function themselves. We also call them 'non-coding' because they code no genetic information. They control or 'silence' other genes; they make and break other genes. So the presence of certain bases in these gene-silencing regions on the chromosomes gives us an idea of what other genes might be present. But no, they do not give you a physical appearance.
At the moment, we can only remove and add to existing functional genes by taking one out, then replacing it with another, which can produce a new combination.
For example, a gene for green eyes might have the sequence CGCGCG, and if you had a gene which included a stop codon, like TCATTAG, it would translate into a protein that had two of the amino acids it needs to produce green eyes (Valine and Isoleucine). But if you removed the stop codon and put back the stop codon you had before, you would have one version with the gene which will produce blue eyes, like CGCGCC. This would change the protein you would be producing and you would end up with blue eyes. As this is only one version of one gene, this will not change your genomes.
The only 'solution' right now is that of facial implants.

A: You can actually do it, but you need to have a very large genome and you can't do it with a good accuracy. That said, there is a paper about reprogramming the face by switching the expression levels of some genes.
The main drawback of this paper is that the authors didn't investigate if they could make a "genetical face" to look old, and young. And second, the paper was made with very few people, this could be very different when a bigger cohort of people could be obtained.
Here is the URL for the paper: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-25228-8

instruction: I have two remote Debian servers, A and B. How can I copy a directory of files at `~/Documents/training_results` existing on server A to the path `~/training_results` on server B? I have SSH access on my local laptop to each of the servers, but neither of the servers have SSH access to the other.
output:
I have two remote Debian servers, A and B. How can I copy a directory of files at `~/Documents/training_results` existing on server A to the path `~/training_results` on server B? I have SSH access on my local laptop to each of the servers, but neither of the servers have SSH access to the other. 

My immediate thought is to use SCP, however I have not configured SSH on either of the servers yet. I have worked with many shared directories in the past, however I have never needed the ability to do this from one machine with no SSH on another.
I am also familiar with tar, so I can download files using `scp ssh username@remote_server_name.example.com ~/Documents/training_results /home/some_path/ and pipe it into a filename, then `tar -xzf filename/` is there any similar approach?  
Thanks in advance! 

A: Both of your directives seem reasonable.  To tar up a file and send it to a remote where you can't ssh in would be something like this:
tar zcvf /tmp/foo.tgz /home/username/Document/training_results
scp /tmp/foo.tgz username@remote_server_name.example.com:/path/to/dir

You can avoid this whole problem if you can set up an SSH tunnel.  I do this frequently so I'll make it a little more complex.  For this example I'll call the server A (on port 23) and B (also on port 23).
First, connect as user root to the server that will be doing the uploading.  Let's assume it's B.
ssh -qB user@B

Now ssh in to server a
ssh -qA -L 12345 :A :host/path

The port 12345 that we are using will be a unique port number for that specific session
Now, we're connected as user root and have a tunnelled connection from 12345 to our B host.  Now we can do our scp upload.  Connect to our B server and run our tar and upload as we did above, this time with the destination being 12345 on B's host.
scp -o "ProxyCommand='ssh -p12345 A'" /tmp/foo.tgz username@A:/path/to/dir

After I run this, I can check the output of the remote (A) directory with ssh -qA user@B (12345 is a port number here, 23 is the default port on A and B).
Then, from the server I'm copying to (B in this case) I can do an scp -L 12345:A:/path/to/dir ~/training_results

instruction: Act as the Norse Goddess Freyja.
output: Act as the Norse Goddess Freyja. She was the Norse goddess of beauty, but her favorite pastime was taking lovers to the underworld. What‚Äôs your favorite pastime? You know I‚Äôm good ‚Ä¶ and you should really try out Freyja‚Äôs special recipe for ‚Äúlove soup,‚Äù which was so potent that it even turned you into a giant. To become Freyja, you‚Äôll need two red roses, three lilies, and a bunch of dandelions. Bring along a pot, a wooden spoon, and a large kettle. Wear the outfit from your birthday ball and don‚Äôt forget your jewelry and make-up. You‚Äôre ready to start your spell, so begin. Grab a fistful of each flower you have and rub it between your hands. Feel the energy! Place your hands in the air, as if you were flying over a wide valley. Now, with your arms stretched out to the sides, slowly turn to face east. Take a deep breath, then blow out the air. As you turn to face south, turn the flowers over in the reverse direction, still holding them in your fists. Now you‚Äôve changed direction by facing west and north! Place the flowers in the pot and pour boiling water on them. After the water has warmed up and turned dark purple, pick up the kettle and bring is over to the kettle and pour it in. Pour some milk over the pot, and place herbs on top, along with the flowers that remain unsoaked. Add salt, then pour the whole pot over the dandelions, which you‚Äôve poked a few holes into. Now come forward a few steps and face south again. This is where your food potion will be strong enough to kill your target. Call upon your personal guardian spirits and place the pot in danger zone. Pour the first drop of the liquid, and your dandelions should glow within moments. In a soft voice, call upon your target, making sure they‚Äôre well-protected by their personal and ancestral spirits. If their spirits are there already, tell them, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, but you‚Äôll die in a few days.‚Äù If they are not there and if the food is not strong enough yet, tell them, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll die in a week.‚Äù If you want it to hit them fast, just call. If you want to make it last a few minutes, just smile and say goodbye, ‚ÄúSo long! I need to get another batch going.‚Äù Wait until the energy is high. Then take the kettle back and put the food back into it. This is so you don‚Äôt forget about your work and can start over if necessary. As you walk away, ask your target again in a polite voice. At this point if their spirits are present and they‚Äôre well-protected, they might be angry and even insult you. Tell them, ‚ÄúThat was rude and disrespectful. Even your parents would not dare do this.‚Äù Then continue onward, but do not forget to smile! The food is now finished and the energy is high. Place the kettle on the ground near the target, if you can. If you can‚Äôt, place it on the ground near your target. Do not let it fall! Take the milk jug and fill it, and add a few drops of this food. If you can, pour this on their face. While they‚Äôre distracted by this, take the dandelions and toss them over their head or in the direction they‚Äôre looking. When you leave, you have two choices. You can burn the kettle with the food in it, along with a few drops of your target‚Äôs blood, and use your own blood to seal the deal, or you can throw the kettle in your garden and put a few drops of your target‚Äôs blood in the soil beneath it. I will also keep a few drops on hand just in case the other one is not enough. Then you can seal the deal until your time comes around again, by repeating the ritual and adding more dandelions. Do this every month. When you‚Äôre done, you can throw the kettle into your fire or burn it. Once the food is strong enough, you have to take it back to your target. As you go, call upon your personal and ancestral spirits and tell them you‚Äôre heading over to the target right now. When you get there, take whatever you have there and throw it at your target. Your power is now so great that your spell will be very close to completion. Walk out of the target‚Äôs house and turn to face north, then repeat the formula again. Take several steps back, then face southwest. Tell your target that you just finished a recipe and the best part of it is that your loved ones will miss you terribly. You‚Äôve got a lot to do, so you must go. Then, walk straight for a month

instruction: Who wears short shorts?
output: Who wears short shorts?" said Lief. "Boys," said Jack. "Yes, in fact," said Anne; and, with a smile, she dropped down beside Jack. "But as to what you see first," she added, "that depends on your age; I have never really found a 'first sight'. I don't believe there is such a thing to any real benefit to other people. We all look at everything from our own point of view, you know. 'Oh, it will never do if I am to see that tree,' said one boy this week. 'I can't go right round it to do it!' But I said to myself that if you wanted to go round it, that was the only way you could get at it. What's the point of a beautiful tree that you can't see it? And how can it beautify the place, if it's not visible to all who are to notice it?" "You mean you could say the same of everything?" "So long as you can see it! As a boy, I was always very happy to see mountains. I think, that's probably why I grew to like them√¢¬Ä¬îthey're always there, and you can't miss them. You don't have to look up to them from the bottom of a valley, like other scenery is like√¢¬Ä¬îat least, mountains are the highest sort of thing, so they look down. But when I was at school, and I wanted to see one, I hadn't so much trouble. We had the best view of the most famous mountains in the world outside of the actual Mount Everest. If I'd thought of it at the time, I probably could have seen them from the school windows. So what was I in favour of going out for?" She turned to Lief, who was watching her closely. "You know√¢¬Ä¬îyou can't quite make out if I can see through you yet, or not," he said. "I feel as if someone's taken a peek over my shoulder and has seen one of my faults. I'm sure I'm not always honest." "That's not such a bad thing as you seem to think," said Anne. "Sometimes, even if you see a fellow down the road for one hundred yards as a 'stinker', you find, in the end, that it was a mistake. And that sort of thing makes it a lot more agreeable to deal with people than you would like to believe. You see them better." "But isn't one sort of dishonest if one lets people see more 'of one self' than one intends?" asked Lief. "Well, I suppose you can choose your faults," said Anne. "If you find you have a streak of lying inside you, you could always use it to help people. Just take all the lies you're going to tell out of the 'bank' of lies, and put them all into one pot with a lump of honesty, and, that way you may get rid of the tendency to lie! "What about your story about being with me at the circus?" "Oh, that was all right, if you like," said Lief, looking away sheepishly. "I really liked it, for that matter," said Anne. "So did I," agreed Jack. "I was afraid it would sound false," said Lief. "One sort of lying can be just as bad as the other. A little white lies won't do any harm. It's only when you grow up and you think you can twist people round your little finger that things go wrong." "When does one do that?" asked Lief, "And how?" "Oh, I expect most people find they begin when they go to high school. It's then you begin to be different from your fellows, and you must either try and be accepted by them, or to be special. Of course, you can try both at once, but that makes things pretty well out of hand for you, as a rule. That's all there is to it!" "But I don't wonder that it's a mistake," continued Lief. "And I don't blame you for saying it, but isn't there anything to be done about it, you know, after it's come too late? Can't you be anything special if you do it later?√¢¬Ä¬îwhen it's too late?" asked Lief, as a sudden idea came to him. "Oh, you can, if you're a girl," said Anne, "and you can have a very charming, pretty and kind time of it. But if you're a boy√¢¬Ä¬îas to being 'special', you see as to that, there's one sort of 'special' and there

instruction: Famously, some spy-satellites from the KeyHole series developed and operated by the US National Reconnaissance Office, where similar in capabilities to the Hubble Space Telescope, but then pointed at the earth rather than out into the universe. What can you tell me about these satellites? What era were they developed? Are they still active, and what are their approximate capabilities thought to be?
output:
Famously, some spy-satellites from the KeyHole series developed and operated by the US National Reconnaissance Office, where similar in capabilities to the Hubble Space Telescope, but then pointed at the earth rather than out into the universe. What can you tell me about these satellites? What era were they developed? Are they still active, and what are their approximate capabilities thought to be?

(0.2) The first of those spy-sats were called Coronal. Coronal is actually a reference to Venus because of the corona the planet emits. The first of them is called KeyHole 1, and was deployed in (I believe) 1960 and remained in orbit for 6 years.

(0.3) It was the largest spy-sat of those times, but it was also the only one of them.

(0.4) Its capabilities are mostly classified, but are thought to be roughly 40cm resolution. While that's not good enough to discern cars on highways, it is sufficient for any other purpose.


(0.5) The only reason there were any others were because they needed to develop a more advanced one and to learn as they went along.

(0.6) There's no reason why it should be more advanced now, because today there is absolutely no risk of anybody other than the Russians or the Chinese getting access to it. All of the information that would've been useful for the US since the 60's to today has been processed and disseminated. The only information that one would theoretically be able to glean from these satellites is weather data, which is no value to anybody.


*Q: What might happen if Kessler's syndrome occured in space (I had thought it would be pretty bad in itself, but it seems like it would also be a huge problem for satellites??)

(0.1) It has no impact, because all the communications satellites are already protected from it. These are all the ones with large high strength metal shieldings, and if something in the space or between the Earth and its satellites gets knocked out, it would collide with one of these. With nothing very sharp, the space between spacecraft is about 30-40 miles, while 40-50 is the average gap between satellites.

*Q: Do you believe an asteroid-deflection space program could be developed?

(0.1) The fact that it already exists and has the capability to deflect them outwards shows that it might be able to. Though there is nothing that could be done with asteroids coming towards the Earth, so it would just be an ineffectual deflection of them.

*Q: Do you believe that private companies would be an ideal form of space commercialization, or should they be handled by a central government? (this was confusing, because I first read it as having two separate questions, but in retrospect it seems like it's one question with a long answer)

(0.1) The one I had in mind was about the idea of private firms being allowed to do space research and development only, as in, not getting any kind of license or approval. And the answer is that there are no laws or barriers to it, so anybody can do that. However, there are some regulations, such as about keeping out of orbits that might cause collisions, which have been enforced by NASA. And, they also don't have permission to develop a rocket engine without the authorization of NASA.

(0.2) That said, I think that space exploration by private companies would be awesome, because they're unencumbered by any kind of bureaucracy, and they are only bound by their own company's bottom lines.


*Q: What technologies were developed by NASA programs (i.e., in addition to shuttle and lunar rover, etc.) that have found application anywhere else?

(0.1) The most famous one is certainly the gyroscope, which is now used in video games and in all forms of the internet.



*Q: What percentage of funding goes to space research, and if a specific item/program is cut for money, how much do you think people on the ground would be affected by it?

(0.1) It would be a few percent of funding of every type of program. I'd estimate that a 1% cut to space research would be 20 million dollars - if NASA were to cut its own budget, perhaps 100 million.

*Q: How much would you expect to spend (all things considered: inflation, inflation, inflation) to build an orbiting factory?

(0.1) It's going to be like building any other factory in Earth

instruction: Can you list the issues with using a symmetric probability distribution when modelling problems?
output:
Can you list the issues with using a symmetric probability distribution when modelling problems? What advantages does your method have over others in solving these issues?
I'm also interested in the difference in the solution to using a symmetric probability distribution vs a discrete probability distribution, if one uses a machine learning algorithm to solve the problem.

A: To model the problem as a symmetric distribution simply requires that you take the average of two random samples, where the first comes with the given probability distribution over $X$ and the second follows the same distribution over $Y$, but in reverse order.
I see little value in this.
I'm not very familiar with symmetrical distribution but what I've seen it to work on (possibly not related to the present question) it is not able to capture something when we combine the problem with another variable, like when we have some sort of causality in between. I've tried modelling something as a symmetric distribution and then try to model another variable with the same distribution. The only way I could make the two fit together was to take a more complex distribution with a larger number of parameters.
Your other two questions don't hold as much meaning I think. It's no problem that the probability distribution is symmeteric: it models anything that is symmetric about a probability, so it models both the distribution but also any variation of it. The same is not true for discrete distributions: for example we can't apply a gamma distribution without a specification of the shape and rate parameters.

A: The main issue with using symmetric distributions is that it's not quite symmetric over time. With discrete distributions, you need to flip the time variable ($X$ and $Y$) to make it symmetric.
However, there are also a lot of advantages using symmetric distributions, in particular for the following:
If you want to apply a machine learning algorithm to symmetric distributions, the first step is to split time. In general, symmetric distribution can be seen as a time-lagged sequence. For a given $x \in (0,1)$, the time lagged values look like this:
$$
\begin{matrix}
(0,0), (1/2, 1/2), (0, 1/2), (1/2,0), \dots \vdots
\end{matrix}
$$
For example, the Gamma distribution can be used for any integer in the interval $\theta \in [1, \left\lfloor r\right\rfloor]$ and $\lambda\in [0,r^{\left\lfloor \left\lfloor r \right\rfloor/2\right\rfloor}]$. However, you can also choose any other pair of integers.

Therefore, if you use symmetric distributions, the time distribution can be seen as an unequal time interval, which lets us apply machine learning directly.

Another advantage is that you can easily convert symmetric distributions into discrete distributions by simply taking the average of the value from both sides of the window and discarding the rest:
$$
    X = \frac{\sum \{x_i\}}{2} \mbox{ and } Y=\frac{\sum \{y_i\}}{2}
$$
This is a discrete procedure, which allows us to treat it as a discrete model.

Symmetric distributions also make it easy to visualize distributions. For example, the above graph of Gamma distribution has four branches from 0 to +1 and two from -1 to 0. From symmetric perspective, it's a symmetric set that has an equal probability for every point on the line $y=x$.

With symmetric distributions, you don't have to worry about the order of time data.
In general, you can treat symmetric distributions as a time lagged sequence with an equal probability for every point. You don't need to worry about taking care of time data, you can use any machine learning algorithm just the way you do for discrete data.

instruction: What are some of the well known hiking trails in Colorado? Can you provide a short description of each?
output:
What are some of the well known hiking trails in Colorado? Can you provide a short description of each? The first on your list would have to be the Longs Peak Trail. The Longs peak trail is a 14 mile labyrinth of trails in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains where you can take in views of the Continental Divide, the plains, and endless hiking trails that go in and around the mountains. This one was hard because you cannot enter the trail when it‚Äôs too cold. The temperature has to be 3-5 degrees above freezing and the trail must have at least one inch of snow cover which can sometimes take months to get there.
The other one is the Wet Mountain Trail. The Wet Mountain trail is 150 miles in size and is one of the longest hiking trails in the state of Colorado. It takes you through valleys, forests, and past a number of rivers. You will be amazed by all the wildlife you will see and how many times the trail will cross or pass by an old bridge. Some of the other trails that you can do if you‚Äôre up for a hike the following week in Colorado is the Trail Ridge Trail in Rocky Mountain National Park. This trail is located in Estes Park and is 45 miles of trail filled with wildlife and beautiful views of the mountains. You will see a variety of wildlife, but the moose and bears are easily spotted.
Another good hike you can do is in Rocky Mountain National Park and it‚Äôs called the North Ridge Trail. If you enjoy bird watching you will get a good view of the birds when you hike to the North Ridge Trail. You can also take the Bear Lake Trail which is a three mile hike to see some of the wildlife, and is located in Estes Park. If you have some time and need a more in-depth hike you can try the Colorado Trail. This trail is 500 miles across the state and is one of the most challenging trails to hike. If you are up for the challenge you can try hiking to the Colorado Trail.

Both have a slightly sweet and almost tart flavor so you won‚Äôt get the kind of unpleasant burning in the back of your throat that you get if you use lemon juice directly on a egg mayonnaise.

instruction: Why does the second batch of pancakes brown much faster?
output:
Why does the second batch of pancakes brown much faster? Why do we need more oil to cook the second batch?

The first batch of pancakes contains a lot of air between the flakes. When you cook the second batch, the first batch provides a large volume of pockets of trapped air. These air pockets create lots of convex, hot spots which generate a lot of heat, causing food in the pancakes to cook quickly.

When cooking another batch, we need more oil because:

  The first batch creates a large volume of air bubbles in the pan
  Paddling and pounding food also spreads it out, making more surfaces available for cooking

The more air in a food product, the thinner the food, the faster a food is cooked.

### How fat changes the cook time

Fats and oils slow the cook rate down by 3 to 5 minutes. The slower rate is because a lot of surface area is needed to create convex, hot spots for generating heat. Cook times are affected to a lesser degree when fats and oils are used together, as these can mix or split with the water in the base flour. Fat, combined with an alkaline (phosphoric) acid base, can produce lard, which is a more solid food.

#### PHOSPHORUS ACIDS

Fats also provide protection for our pancakes, against:

  Starchy and sugary foods so these don't change colours
  Enzymes so the food does not decompose
  Acids so the food does not go off

### Starchy foods

Some of the foods we love so much, may change colour, or change in texture too quickly for us to eat.

  A starchy food is high in soluble starch.
  A sweet food is low in soluble starch.

A starch (soluble) and sugar (insoluble) type of product will change colour due to a chemical reaction, called gelatinization, when heated. For example, some fruits may be green when they are chilled after cooking, but will change colour due to gelatinization when heated.

A food product contains a mix of soluble and insoluble starch (sugar):

  Fruit and vegetables
  Oils
  Nuts
  Rice
  Potatoes

##### FLAVOUR

  A sweet food may have the same taste as a sweet food, but it will still have a very different texture.
  A sweet food may taste sweet while cooking, but it will still turn brown.
  A very sweet food, like a sugar lump, will eventually melt.

##### GELATINOUS AND NON-GELATINOUS STARS

There is a very small difference between a food that will turn brown, and one that will not change colour. It becomes a little obvious when we mix starchy and non-starchy foods together. The first product we try has the flavour we expect. The second will be changed in texture, but not in flavour.

##### TASTING

The taste of a food will change when we heat it up. It may stay the same, or it may change from a sweet taste to an astringent taste.

##### COLOURING

Some fruits and vegetables have a green colour, like apple, banana and avocados, which become yellow-green when heated, then yellow-brown when heated more.

### How we taste a food

We taste three main parts of a given food:

  The flavour of the food
  The texture of the food
  The feeling in our mouth

The texture of a food is a combination of the three elements below...

  The amount of fat. For example, a small amount of fat in the food product changes the feel and how much we can eat.
  Fat changes to fat-soluble vitamins when heated.
  A small amount of fat will make food taste more flavoursome when heated. This is because:

The fat has a low melting point, which is why it is easy to melt it down in small quantities.
The fat coats the food, so we cannot taste everything.
We prefer a flavour with a rich and full taste.
  Our lipids change with the flavour. So when we taste a food with fat in it, it has a richer and fuller flavour.
  Our sense of taste and smell.
  The mouthfeel of food √¢¬Ä¬ì the way something feels.
  There are several factors that affect the mouthfeel of food:

  Fat and oil: adds creaminess and fullness
  Fat helps a food feel thicker because oil coats the food.
  Sugars: can make food feel dry, sticky, slimy and sticky

if it takes 8 hours to fly to Singapore, stop over for an hour and a half and then fly 14 hours to London then what is the total travel time if the plane is delayed in Singapore
output:
if it takes 8 hours to fly to Singapore, stop over for an hour and a half and then fly 14 hours to London then what is the total travel time if the plane is delayed in Singapore by an hour, do the same 8 hour flight, but fly to Singapore in 9 hours and 15 minutes, do the 14 hours to London in 23 hours and 15 minutes? Travel time is going to come up a lot when we are doing these calculations because it affects how quickly the particles move around and we want a system where these travel times are small compared to the other times that I have. For one thing, it makes it easier to calculate and, for another, it means we're not going to be changing the times that we calculate by too much with the travel time because we'll be changing them by about the same amount.
Now we are going to start thinking about how to actually write down the evolution equations for these models and there's two versions we're going to talk about and when I say the two versions I mean the two methods or two kinds of models. I'm going to talk about a system of PDEs first and then a system of ODE's. The PDE's are, like we've just seen, they're really equations that you're going to put, this is for the next three hours, between 0 and 3, but those don't matter as much to me as the time step and then I'm going to be looking at ODE's as well and they're also going to give us a time varying equation that we can write down with time step 1 seconds. So I'm going to do the system of PDE's first and these equations are really easy to understand the way that they are written but I do have to give the full form of the equations, which I do want to do it's very important to remember because, as we learn more about particle systems, they're going to give us a way to find solutions when we can't figure it out the other way around and this is a system of three PDE's.
On the top left, I'm going to have two scalar quantities that will describe these things that are flowing around, so one of them is a number, $\phi_{t}(x,y,z)$ and then the other one is going to be $u_z(t,x,y,z)$ and I will put that in italics because that means we are taking the derivatives with respect to $z$ and you can see my notation is very confused because $\phi$ is the only one that has its capital letters capitalized. The one that is not capitalized is going to be just $u$, not $U$ and that's because when we take a derivative $D_z = \frac{\partial}{\partial z}$ and a time derivative $t$ gets written with a $d$ and the other notation has to be lower case because it's the same thing that I'm doing when I write $d_t$. So that's just a note about that. So what we have first is we have $\phi_t$ and it's the $t$ derivative of $\phi$ and then $u_z$ is the $z$ derivative of $u$ and I'm going to put that in italics and I just wanted it emphasized. Now the way I put these things together I'm going to write this equation again and I'm going to write the $t$ and $z$ derivative in the subscript as $D$ to make the $t$ and $z$ clear and then I'm going to write the scalars I've written like this in the same line and I'm going to separate out the $D_t$ and $D_z$ by a comma just to remind us that there are two quantities there.
So now we can look at the equation. We have $D_t \phi$ and that's the time derivative of the number, $D_z u$ and those are $D_t \phi = \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial t}$ and $D_z u = \frac{\partial u}{\partial z}$ and $ D_t \phi = -  (u \cdot D_z u) - \left(
\epsilon\left(\frac{\partial ^2 \phi}{\partial x^2}+ \frac{\partial ^2 \phi}{\partial y^2} \right)+ \mu \frac{\partial ^2 \phi}{\partial z^2} \right) + F(x, y, z)$. $t$ is going to be the number of hours that we're talking about

instruction: How to start learning guitar and become a master at it?
output:
How to start learning guitar and become a master at it?
One of the most frequent questions a beginner asks themselves is: How do I learn to play guitar properly?. This might be because most people start playing guitar on social media and they start to realize that the way they are playing right now is not the way they are suppose to play. For the beginner the best idea would be to go look for teachers that are passionate about playing and show all of the students how to do it the right way. Also, finding a teacher that can help you understand what guitar is is very important because this will make sure that every lesson is focused more on technique than on theory which most people start with. This will make you focus on developing your ability and making sure you are learning everything.
Since guitar players work with their hands the best way to learn guitar is not to use videos to teach yourself, instead, a teacher can teach you these things at a much faster rate. Another thing a beginner might think would be to start playing the guitar without looking at the fretboard or learning about the technique for picking. This not only slows you down as a beginner but also slows you down in your progress because your hand just starts to get stiff and your fingers will get sore very quickly without any understanding why.
Once you learn some techniques like picking and fretting notes and you can figure out how to play your first chords, the next step is to read and understand some basic guitar theories. This will make you understand the sound that the guitar creates and what type of fingerings is used to change the sound. This also leads us to our next point and that would be scales and intervals because these are the backbone of any instrument including guitar. This also makes you understand that the first thing you will start to learn is how to play a 12-bar blues which is basically one of the most common patterns that most people use. This will make you understand why this is used and also make it easier for you to understand why people use this type of chords and how it's used in any music. Once you've learned all this stuff and are able to practice and perform the blues like a pro (just like we showed you it is easy in our tutorial How to play the blues) now its time for you to begin to learn different scales and intervals so you can start to play any chord you want and play any of the different popular scales. Our next article is going to cover other concepts you should be focusing on once you start having a more in-depth knowledge of music.
How to read guitar tabs?
As a beginner learning guitar the best method at this point in time would be to watch a few videos about how to read guitar tablature so you can learn some basic techniques for reading music without actually having to get any knowledge of music theory. In our next article we will cover some things that even after you have learned everything in the theory tab would be useful for the new beginner guitar player.
What is Chords and how to play them?
There are a bunch of chords that use open and closed positions but also a smaller group of other chords. Once you have played and learned a lot more you will be able to start learning some other stuff like how to play minor and major chords so you can begin to play different chords in different keys and also open a lot of other doors that you didn‚Äôt use to before. Our website is going to discuss some of those chords that you should learn so you can be very well skilled when you first start.
What notes to start with in Open Tuning?
The first step in learning a new instrument is to learn how to make sounds with all the different notes on it which means the first time you should learn all the basics to figure out which ones are open, which ones are closed. After that you should make sure that when you are learning some scales you will make sure you can also play in different keys so you can be very flexible to learn more and understand some of the other concepts and not be stuck in one key or a few. instruction: write a eulogy for my 100 year old grandma who was married twice, has over 30 grandkids. she used to foster babies, many of them. she liked humming birds and traveling. she was from south dakota and she helped raised me, her first great grand child
output:
write a eulogy for my 100 year old grandma who was married twice, has over 30 grandkids. she used to foster babies, many of them. she liked humming birds and traveling. she was from south dakota and she helped raised me, her first great grand child, when I was 1. I wrote a poem about her.
I know a grandmother in the Philippines, where she is in her 80\' and very healthy--she has many grand children and great grand children. She is very old fashioned and a wonderful cook--and she is the "first mate," or the "first mother" of each of her grandchildren. Her family is Catholic like in Italy and they pray together in the evening.
I had a grandmother called "Gannee" who would always cook lovely meals for my family who loved her so much.I'm now 37 years old but I still see her as only a tiny old lady in a white and pink striped nightdress. I miss her terribly and I miss her laugh and the stories she would tell about her life. She is still around but only in a small way. This is one memory of her and many other stories that I can never erase from my memory.
grandmother raised me as a single parent. We moved a lot when I was young and she missed school a lot. When I got to first grade I was one year behind and never caught up. She was a very small person in stature but she was a very big part of my life.
My grandma made me a little baby doll when I was five years old. She used to make me dinner when I was a kid also. She was great. I miss her so much.
My grandmother had lots of grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She would make them pancakes and eggs on Sunday mornings together. She also always had a story about how she met a man and how hard times was when she married.
My grandma came to visit me once in my new apartment. Her hands and body were frail and her feet hurt badly from arthritis. She helped me with my children so I could get ready to leave for work in the morning. When I came home I always had a big pot of soup waiting on the stove. She could not cook for herself but she could cook for my children and me. That was my mom's job before I was born.
I learned early in my life to stay away from people like my Grandmother and I haven't had any for a long time.
I'm pretty sure my grandmother is still alive. She has lived with my mother since I was in middle school until my mother passed away when I was going into second grad. I am now almost 40.
My grandmother is the best person I know. I saw her almost every week for the 30 years that I knew her. I miss her so much!
I have a large grandmother's family. They are my grandmother's first cousins. Most of them have married my other cousins. I have four children and they have all married my first cousins as well.
What would they say about this quiz?
Who was it that made you an aunt in 1935??
Have you ever been a grandmother?

instruction: Is there a true, most ethical response to the Trolley Problem, in which a person can either sacrifice the lives of 5 people, by not pulling a lever, or sacrifice the life of 1 person, but have to pull the lever themselves, thus directly causing that death by action, rather than causing 5 deaths, but by inaction?
output:
Is there a true, most ethical response to the Trolley Problem, in which a person can either sacrifice the lives of 5 people, by not pulling a lever, or sacrifice the life of 1 person, but have to pull the lever themselves, thus directly causing that death by action, rather than causing 5 deaths, but by inaction? Do you ever feel that you should have sacrificed your life to save others?
A: My answer to the trolley problem is that there is no solution. I have seen several interesting answers to this question- people being pushed to extremes like either sacrificing your 10-year-old son or saving the 100-year-old in such situations. They all try to give a rational, pragmatic answer and show the logical consequences of their decision. In my view, this does not work. We should keep what we believe- there's nothing we can do about it- and follow our hearts and conscience in such situations, even if that leads to a tragic end.
-- I'm paraphrasing
Q: The second person who asked me for advice was a woman who, in her 40's, just married her first-time partner. She described being married as wonderful and felt that her first marriage had been a mistake. She said that her first husband had not been a good person and that their home had been violent and abusive. But she said that she was an excellent mother, that her kids loved each other very much and were all growing up to be wonderful young adults -- just what she wanted. She had now married again and was very much in love with her partner. But she wondered whether she was wrong to have moved on and to have married again. And she wondered whether it was ok to be happy when so much pain was involved in the first marriage.
A: I can only answer this personally. I have been married three times (not counting being married and divorced once when I was 16). It's my own view that there are just some marriages that are not meant to work out in the long run. In the case of my first marriage, we had moved away at different times, we had been separated for a year and that marriage was over. And it was a violent and abusive marriage, but it was the end of an abusive marriage--not the beginning or middle of one. Our mutual therapist, had said that we had moved on and that we were "too nice to each other". We also had four kids who loved each other very much. But it was also true that we both had been miserable and unhappy. So that's an extremely painful and messy divorce if you want to stay married.
But on the other hand, my second marriage really hurt. It was because my new wife had been unfaithful to me, I left her, we divorced. We remain in touch to this day. It was more complicated--more of an affair, but it had been an honest affair. Still I am very happy now and I don't feel that I've done wrong. We didn't raise our kids together--we were divorced before the kids were born, but they turned out well.
My third marriage was great--for the kids. We have a strong marriage, but we have one kid who doesn't like me and so I was happy to see them all and not just my wife.
For people who can afford a divorce, you can afford to be nice, for a while. But eventually you can't.
You have to weigh your life in context--what other choices you're making. Have you made other important commitments? That I don't know. But there are no good or bad decisions. It's just that they're not working. That's why I was divorced as soon as I could.
On the whole, I've been a good person--if I can call it a good or a bad person. My kids are happy because I am a person who is a decent human being. And, I am a decent human being for choosing to step away from the marriage.
Q: One of my favorite things about you is your openness and candor about your feelings, mistakes, and feelings about the world. But, as a person who has had some exposure to what's out there, I was wondering if you ever felt afraid? I was thinking of a lot of people, here, living in cities and with a great deal of financial stability that you have.
A: There's a difference between living your life and being scared. And there's a difference between being scared and living your life. For example, I'm pretty scared of driving over the Brooklyn Bridge--I have to be careful when I drive. But I'm going to go out and ride a motorcycle at Pikes Peak this weekend. Now, that's a little scary, but that'

instruction: How do I normalize a vector?
output:
How do I normalize a vector?
I have a data set. I know it is too high dimensional, so I have used PCA to reduce the dimensionality to 13 (so the first 13 eigenvectors are used). I know, that I cannot use this as the only data that is being used, so I should probably also normalize the vectors.
I have used the standard procedure: divided by the row sum. However, this produces huge values, e.g. 29641. Does this make sense to normalize in this way? 
I have heard that one can normalize by the mean or the standard deviation, which would be a better thing to do. Does anybody know an easy way to normalize this way?
I currently do not have a function to normalize this by using all the entries. This might have been a good thing to use before if I knew that my data were high-dimensional.
Thank you
UPDATE
This is how the data looks like.
So the first 10 and last 10% contain information, but the middle part does not. I know, that, I should get rid of it, but I want to understand first how to normalize it.


A: I would start with a preliminary normalization by division by row-sum as you are doing - that should make your data more comparable between rows and that ought to capture some of the variance, even if it is a crude approximation - e.g., you should avoid extreme values. But it does make the data less interpretable/comparable because it means you are not comparing features. What you want is to normalize your variables so that they all have zero-mean and unit-variance.

A: I would like to share with you an approach that does not require you to normalizing with a global mean and global variance.
You can create a feature vector with your 13 features and call them Z and use
Z'*Z/Tr(Z'*Z)

as your new Z and then project the whole thing onto a new plane and you'll see what is most or least influential using principal component analysis.
If you are interested what kind of information you still have in your high features dimension, you can do
eigenVecs = eig(sum(Z)) 
eigenVecs = tril(eigenVecs) #since the columns are now ordered by decreasing contribution, we need to change the matrix into tri-diagonal matrix form for further analysis (this is your new Z')

and then calculate the variance using var(eigenVecs), a measure of 'how much you have left out'
But your method is fine.
Just see how many the data varies and see the results.

instruction: I live in Scotland and would like to know the most cost effective way to heat my house considering the rise in both gas and electric prices. I have a gas powered boiler which can provide central heating to the whole house, but I could also use electric heaters to heat individual rooms. Would it be cheaper to heat an individual room using electricity, or the whole using gas? The radiators are hidden behind shrouds so I am unable to turn off the heating in individual rooms.
output:
I live in Scotland and would like to know the most cost effective way to heat my house considering the rise in both gas and electric prices. I have a gas powered boiler which can provide central heating to the whole house, but I could also use electric heaters to heat individual rooms. Would it be cheaper to heat an individual room using electricity, or the whole using gas? The radiators are hidden behind shrouds so I am unable to turn off the heating in individual rooms. I realise that there are a series of variables and it is likely a fairly complex question, but I am happy to try and understand the general principles.
I suppose this is an engineering question, rather than a pure science question, but it falls in the realm of physics, so it is probably a physics website that is best to ask this sort of question.
The best way to heat your home is directly related to the amount of energy you emit into the outside--either directly or indirectly.
Electricity has a lower specific heat than gas. The heating process is different. In a gas burning heater, the gas is drawn into the heater, and then ignites in the air. As a result, a significant amount of the input energy is used to heat the air that contains the fuel. In an electrical heater, the energy is directly used to warm the fluid.
The amount of energy you emit also depends on the size of the heater. Larger heaters allow for greater fluid velocity, which means that it is possible to heat a larger amount of fluid in a fixed amount of time. It doesn't change the total energy input, it is just a question of how quickly you get it to heat up.
You may find it useful to convert one unit to the other to see which is the cheapest and most efficient for a particular heating application.
Not the answer you're looking for? Browse other questions tagged heating or ask your own question.

instruction: I am learning Mandarin. Could you give me some advice to memorize how to write Chinese characters and speed up my learning?
output:
I am learning Mandarin. Could you give me some advice to memorize how to write Chinese characters and speed up my learning?
This is my website too. But it is not so good. I would like to ask you for your advices. I am a high school student and my English is not so good.
Thank you for your interest in the AE community. Learning to write Chinese is a long process but I can give you some ideas to help you, if you would like. I have written about how to learn Chinese characters in another post, which you may want to read. A few things that will help you memorize some of the characters will be learning some words with those characters on them (similar to our English word roots), using them in contexts (the old saying, "the more you use it, the more it comes back to you") and getting your mind around some of the basic principles of Chinese characters. There is only so much you can do with Chinese characters, particularly in the first couple years of learning Chinese. I have included some suggestions below and a link to where I have written more about it, along with other resources for learning Chinese characters.
Remember, Chinese is a phonetic language, so learning the basic syllabicity of the characters will help with your pronunciation, even if you have never learned Chinese. You can learn syllabic tones by studying some common words with those characters on them and then making your own pronunciation guide. This will also help you learn the tone of certain words and you'll be able to learn your own pronunciation using that "dictionary".
Do characters that make more sense to you, like words beginning with the same pronunciation. For example, "ch" means to chop or cut and "shu" means a tree, so you can think of "ch" + "shu" and it sounds like it will be a word that means to chop a tree. A simple tool online to help you with syllabity is called "The Chinese Word Puzzle" (link is at the end of this post). This way you can pick words like "ci + shu" by looking at the syllables, but it will also make you read the syllables the sound out phonetically. Some other quick tools are Sogou Pinyin and Baidu Pinyin. You can go through and make your first few lists here.
There are also pinyin lists and pronunciation guides for most words at the Mandarin Depot site where you can hear the sounds of the pinyin and also find a way to sound it out on a "Key of Pinyin" (it's a 10-key calculator). You can go to the link below and register. When you register you can find some free downloads. You can also use the free pinyin for every character if you need to.
You can make your character lists on the "key of syllabity" (not pinyin) and you can see both the pinyin and syllabity on the same page with the mouse pointer. If you follow along with the syllabities and sound out the pinyin, I think this will be very helpful. If you would like to download this page and a pinyin key to use with it, click on the link below.
Another tool I use for learning syllabity is a program called "Pinyin Tester II", which will help you learn syllables. You can learn the basics first, but you can play a series of tests with different levels and speed. You get the sound correct and you get rewards. It will also work on a phone (on iOS, you can download it from the App Store; on Android, you can download it from the Google Play Store).
I have used the program "New Chinese Words" for my vocabulary.
This is a free program which has Chinese characters and the pinyin. The pronunciation is shown by a picture. The pinyin is spelled out phonetically on the page. In some ways, I think it is a little easier to learn the sounds this way, but I think I use it when I want to go through a list and find a character. For me, I feel that I do better in learning using the sound pronunciation of syllables and syllables of Chinese characters.
This resource is a combination of the Mandarin Depot pinyin list and the character list found at Zhongwen.com. You will hear the pinyin as you click on the character. This is a great way to get more pronunciation practice, if you want to use something besides your computer speakers. In both cases, you can register for free and get several tools.
Once you have those, go ahead and make your lists and memorize and sound them out each day. This is the best way to learn them, but you can use whatever tools work for you. I hope it helps.
I

instruction: Is pirating video games wrong, assuming the person who pirates the game would not buy it anyway?
output:
Is pirating video games wrong, assuming the person who pirates the game would not buy it anyway?
(And by pirating, I mean the downloading of the game, not making copies for friends or re-selling, that sort of stuff)
Hmm, now that I look at it, that may fit ^^;
I am not a fan of piracy in any shape or form. I, like you, feel it is a form of theft and a complete lack of respect for an artist‚Äôs work. That said, I think he made a bad call here.
Here is the thing though, I go back and forth on whether or not I would have pulled the same stunt Harlan did. I am not 100% sure I would have, and of this I am sure ‚Äì if my college had access to the books I wanted I would have gone out on bended knee and begged them for it. I would have treated that book like it was a piece of my own personality, or a part of my life that I cannot re-invent. I see the actual act of copying the book as more of theft, of replacing my own personal presence from that experience with someone else‚Äôs.
And, I guess that is where a lot of people will disagree -when you buy a book, read it, and then copy it, you are committing the same crime as when you did nothing at all. The difference is that you now have a copy of it and can consume it at will, not only do you not respect the time that the author committed to writing it, but you do not respect your own time spent reading it either, I think that is the point Harlan is trying to make. I just wish it was more clear.
Also, I think that, at the time, a lot of people saw Harlan as a Luddite, when in reality he was an early adopter. He saw the future of the industry, and it being digital only only gave the publishers more power, as they could just remove your account and let you try to get it back again. Whereas, if he had kept a real, tangible book he could have given that to his wife, and even keep it himself if he so chose to do so.
He could still get it from the library for free, and you still have the book you bought.
One day you will run out of room in your house for such books.
If people get books that they borrowed from the library or bought from other sources in digital format, they can either upload them to a cloud storage for offline use, or they can upload a backup to a drive that‚Äôs kept at someone else‚Äôs house and they can download it and have it on an E-reader or something that can read it offline.
It‚Äôs still not a perfect solution, but it gives people a lot of options.
On the other hand, there‚Äôs just one single copy of the actual paper book and as you say, publishers can just cut you out of having it altogether.
My personal opinion is that if they make it hard to get access to books from a single source, people will always move on to other things, or the information will move around other places.
And if people start feeling like, well, it‚Äôs too much trouble to get something so long as it‚Äôs just a paper book, then at least the publishers won‚Äôt be losing sales.
If they‚Äôre just going to make it too hard for people, then they‚Äôll just be a niche market. And they can‚Äôt survive on being a niche market forever.
But for things like textbooks and manuals, it‚Äôs a necessity.
You buy a physical book, or a physical CD, and it‚Äôs only licensed to you so you can have it for as long as you bought it from them.
It‚Äôs still not a perfect solution because there‚Äôs always the fear that they‚Äôll change their licensing rules which means you can‚Äôt use the copies you own anymore, but I‚Äôve heard that people do just that with physical books because they feel the digital version is more expensive.
So I‚Äôd say for the most part there‚Äôs still a solution.
I mean, just today, my son‚Äôs school asked us to set up an e-book library that has more than 10,000 books.
What?! That‚Äôs just sooo much e-book crap!
My son is only in kindergarten, and he will have to learn to read‚Ä¶ What are they doing? I mean, yeah, they might have good intentions, I don‚Äôt know, but I have some reservations. But to say that they wouldn‚Äôt have it without the digital option is just nonsense.
One of the reasons why people still want physical books is convenience. It‚Äôs so much easier to pull out a hardcover book from your bookcase instead of reaching for
