instruction: Think of topics that are most common in classic interview questions for a job in computer science.
output:
Think of topics that are most common in classic interview questions for a job in computer science. For example, ‚ÄúHow would you best describe yourself?‚Äù or ‚ÄúHow to you handle being stressed?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat kind of atmosphere do you need in your work environment?‚Äù What types of things do you try to avoid thinking about?
How do you want to be judged?
There are times when you will be judged on your appearance. This might include a job interview or a sports competition. The way that people see you can affect whether you get the job or whether you win the competition.
In the past, many people thought that attractive people were likely to be judged more positively than others. There was also a belief that people who had less power (in the case of job interviews) were unlikely to be judged negatively about their appearance. These ideas were challenged and some were even dismissed. Today we can see that it is hard to tell how someone is judged about their appearance. Therefore, how you judge someone‚Äôs appearance can depend on how attractive you see someone. You are likely to be less critical of other people if you find them attractive.
In your next job interview or social situation, think about how your appearance is likely to be judged. What do you expect people to be thinking about your appearance?
Can you think of a time in which a person was judged about their appearance? Were the expectations influenced by appearance or was this about other things?
Do you think that your ability to dress well will help you to be judged more positively? How is your behaviour likely to be judged?
Ways to use and evaluate the self-talk that is on offer.
How do you think they feel about your questions? Are these things that they would never think about doing? Are they likely to be comfortable with answering such questions honestly?
Do they get annoyed with you? Why do you think this? Does it matter?
Do you think that you are being honest? Do you think that you are making a difference by asking these questions?
This activity is about the question of self-awareness. Sometimes we don‚Äôt really know what we are thinking or feeling. When we do something that we don‚Äôt really want to do, it might be because we don‚Äôt understand what is behind our behaviour. It might be better if we were able to know how we feel and what is influencing our behaviour even when we‚Äôre not really aware of it. To do well, we need to be able to listen to and understand our own thoughts and feelings. It‚Äôs good to ask for help from others so that we can learn more about what is going on for us.
Have you ever asked someone for help to make sense of something? If you have, what was it that you wanted from the other person?
Have you ever tried to work out what you wanted without asking other people? How well did this work out? Did you think their help was useful?
What questions work best when you are asking other people for help? How good are you at asking questions to get your answers?
What is it that you need to find out from the other person? How difficult it this to ask these questions? Do you think it is fair on that person?
Did you get the answers that you wanted? Which answers were useful and important to you? Which were not? Why do you think that?
How honest are you with your friends?
Do you let them know what you are really thinking?
Do you try to cover up things that you are not happy with?
If someone asked you for your help, would you help them?
Would you encourage someone else to help themselves?
Do you know where everyone is in the room at any given time?
It is really easy to become overwhelmed by our own thoughts. The way we think about ourselves and what is important to us can vary enormously. Our thoughts about ourselves can change over a period of time. In the next activity, you will find it useful to think about what you are currently thinking about yourself.
How is your body? Do you take care of yourself in the way that you deserve?
How are your friends? Are you having problems with your friends?
What do you think are the causes of the problems in your relationship? Is there one thing that you would like to change?
How do you feel about your work? What are your hopes for your work in the future?
What are your likes and dislikes? Where do you find pleasure? Where are you going to have to work hard?
These are all thoughts that you currently have in your head. If you can‚Äôt think of any thoughts that are important to you, then there is something different going on. Remember that we often think about things that are very important to us and not that others things. It is very common to have thoughts that seem very important to us but not very important to the rest of the world. How you think about these things is a good

Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.

output:
You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.

Finally! After a while of shooting in the dark and frantically fiddling with sample inputs on the whiteboard, you've came up with an algorithm for solving the coding question your interviewer gave you.
Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"

This is where the skill of listening to interviewers during coding interviews can make or break your performance.
After you've sat through so many coding interviews with the above scenario play out, you know you'll eventually be able to make sense of the new approach.
So most interviewers are given free reign to change the problem if they so choose.
This is one of the reasons why it's so difficult to write down a standard algorithm to solve any particular problem.
Different people have different approaches to the same problem, and sometimes those approaches will be entirely different.

Here's how you can improve your listening and communication skills:

Make eye contact with your interviewer while you think through the problem.
Avoid fidgeting, doodling, or speaking out loud while you're thinking.
Focus on listening to the interviewer's problem description, not just the input you were given.
Consider asking more questions if you need clarification. (Don't ever rely on assumption, and if you don't understand what the hell your interviewer is talking about, just ask them to slow down.)
When your interviewer has finished asking their question, pause for about 5 seconds and think through your approach.
Listen to the interviewer's problem description again.
Ask questions if you need clarification -- or if you feel like you don't understand what the hell you're supposed to do. (The "assumption" problem is easy to avoid by just asking a couple questions to determine if you're on the right track.)
Ask for some clarification for your approach, and ask for time to think about it.
Write down your main thoughts, not the entire algorithm.
Tell your interviewer how long you'll need to think about it.
Think through your problem and how it'll be implemented in the real world.
(We'll talk about this in "How to Interview".)
When you've reached a solution, write down the first thing your interviewer is likely to want to know:
Your key data structures.
What they do, and why.
Your first algorithmic steps.
An example of how you're likely to use your approach in the real world.
What are some alternative algorithms?

In the end, your interviewer won't know exactly how to interview you unless you help them.
Your interviewer won't know if you're able to do a particular task until you get the interviewer to actually do that task with you.

So listen intently to everyone who interviews you.
You won't get the chance to code interview for another year or 10 years, but you will get a unique opportunity to spend one hour talking with an experienced computer scientist.
Take this opportunity to learn and grow.

===

## How to Interview: The Fundamentals

Now that we've discussed how interviewers like to be interviewed, let's talk about how you're likely to actually be interviewed.

First up, let's talk about what the hell is going on when an employer conducts a coding interview.
Your prospective employer is interested in whether or not you can solve specific problems (coding problems!) to a satisfying standard.
When you're an interviewee, you want to show the interviewer how you do this.
This is why you're asked to write code for your interviews -- it forces you to write code for the problem they posed to you.

A standard coding interview lasts about 30 minutes.
During the first 15 minutes or so, your interviewer will go over your resume and ask you some basic questions.
Maybe the interviewer will give you a code sample, or a paper reference, to review.
This is a good time to evaluate the situation and feel out how much you're going to enjoy working with your interviewer.
After all, the interviewer is ultimately trying to determine which of you two candidates would be worth bringing on to build an

Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;

Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine.
output:
The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.

Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine. Zinc deficiency is known to cause several health problems including lowered immunity, abnormal growth, hearing problems, cancer, etc.

Zinc plays an important role in the metabolism of insulin. Zinc deficiency has been linked to hyperandrogenic syndrome, a condition that involves higher levels of male hormones in women which can cause their breasts to become enlarged and look feminine (see Appendix B on page 243).

Zinc also plays a crucial role in hair growth. Zinc deficiency has been associated with hair loss. The deficiency can also lead to low testosterone levels and a feeling of hopelessness and depression.

In addition, zinc is necessary for reproduction because it stimulates sperm production in men and helps to improve women's fertility.

Zinc also plays an important role in the structure of protein and is needed for normal bone development.

Zinc deficiency can impair bone development.

Zinc deficiency can inhibit proper bone

development.

Adequate zinc is essential for the treatment of hyperactivity and poor

learning abilities (1).

In the development of fetal and newborns (fetusses and infants)

(2), the role of zinc is crucial.

Zinc is directly involved in the development of fetuses

(3) and newborns.

Zinc deficiency is responsible for malnutrition of newborns (fetuses)

(4), which affects the way the brain develops.

Zinc deficiency affects the structure of DNA and RNA and damages the cells.

Zinc deficiency inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA, which affects the structure and

function of all cells and causes cell damage (5).

The results of extensive studies show that the function of zinc plays an important role in the protection the body against the aging process.

The role of zinc in the protection of the cells against damage caused by free radicals is

exhaustively documented (see Ref. 6).

The results of the extensive research show that zinc protects

our cells from damage caused by free radicals

(excess electron activity).

Zinc participates in the formation of the immune cells.

Zinc reduces the amount of pro-inflammatory cytokines, and

increases the amount of anti-inflammatory cytokines.

Zinc reduces the amount of pro- and anti-inflammatory

cytokines, thus contributing to the production of a balanced immune system.

Zinc activates T cells, which is responsible for the body's natural defense

against pathogens.

Zinc deficiency causes an increase in the number of lymphocytes,

which are responsible for the body's natural defense against

pathogens.

Zinc activates the T cells of the lymph nodes, which is responsible for

the body's protection against pathogens.

Zinc reduces the number of lymphocytes that are responsible

for the body's natural defense against pathogens.

Adequate supplementation with zinc (8mg daily for women and 11mg for men) can increase the number of T cells by up to 6 times (2).

If we take into account the fact

that:

T cells (including natural killer cells) are

responsible for the body's natural defense against

pathogens,

the supplementation with zinc in the recommended dosage

can increase the natural defense system of the body against

pathogens tenfold.

Zinc deficiency, and therefore high levels of inflammation

in the organism, also imposes significant metabolic

burdens on the body, which, in turn, is a significant driver

of all the other health conditions.

The metabolic burden caused by excessive inflammation

(caused by zinc deficiency) is a major contributor to aging

and degenerative diseases.

Pro-inflammatory cytokines, also known as acute phase reactants,

caused zinc deficiency, increase inflammation and the risk of chronic

diseases.

Inflammation, oxidative stress, and overproduction of

glucocorticoids increase the risk of

disease

Zinc deficiency, as well as the pro-inflammatory state,

increase the risk of diseases;

Inflammation also causes oxidation (damage to the cell membranes),

which increases the risk of further damage to our organs,

and therefore disease

instruction:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:‚àö2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht D√ºrer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:‚àö2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht D√ºrer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting. The French sculptor √âmile-Antoine Bourdelle and the Dutch printmaker Kees Verwey expressed themselves through mathematics.

Many artists with a mathematical training have worked in an academic setting where they studied art history or worked on applied arts such as posters and graphics. Although they often have worked on purely abstract compositions, some also have made work with a mathematical basis. This has taken the form of art objects, such as the mathematical constructions associated with the Dada artist Man Ray, and the geometrical designs of Theo van Doesburg. In modern sculpture and installation art, three-dimensional and spatial forms often have been explored, e.g., by Marcelo C√≠cero; others, such as Carl Andre, Robert Morris, Richard Serra, Robert Smithson, and Bruce Nauman, have explored geometry in spatial art. Other artists who have worked with geometry are Jean (Hans) Arp, John Grillo, Henri Michaux and Yves Tanguy, while other, including the late 19th-century sculptor Alexander Calder and the German-American artist Georg Trakl, have worked with non-Euclidean geometry. The geometric work of Robert Hudson is one of his best-known. The work of the minimalist sculptor Richard Long explores the geometry and mathematics of the natural world. Many performance artists such as Robert Rauschenberg and Yvonne Rainer explored mathematics and the form of the stage. Yoko Ono has worked with mathematics for a long time; and the mathematicians John Conway and John Horton Conway, John H. Conway and James Tanton in painting. In music, mathematical aesthetics has had a long history. In the 20th and 21st centuries, several composers have explored geometrical forms in music.

Since 2007, the Science Museum in London has run a large exhibition of historical and modern works of art and art objects connected to mathematics and geometry. A new exhibition of modern art and the arts of mathematics has been planned for the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam.

Abstract art
Art and mathematics
Art of mathematics
Beauty in mathematics

References

Further reading

  The article focuses mainly on contemporary mathematics.

Mathematicians
Mathematics and art

instruction:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.

In 1966 the United Nations's General Assembly Resolution 2200a was passed, requiring that the exporting nation "take due account of the interests and concerns of the exporting countries and make efforts to encourage and promote cooperation between exporting and importing states in connection with the fair and equitable treatment in international trade". These efforts culminated in the creation of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in 1961, which has its own guidelines on what constitutes "fair and equitable trading."

There is also increasing awareness of the need for fair labour practices in other fields, such as the production of automobiles, computer equipment, pharmaceuticals, and the apparel industry. In the United States, the 1992 passage of the "Clayton Antitrust Act" forced companies to publicly announce their efforts to improve production practices. It was also during the 1990s that the United States government began to pass legislation enforcing the use of corporate "social responsibility" as a means of maintaining competitive advantage in global markets.

These policies have encouraged firms to take an active role in improving the economic conditions of both domestic and foreign suppliers, which have themselves begun to provide greater access to health care, education, and other benefits to those people directly or indirectly involved in their production. This has resulted in a greater awareness, among consumers and other parties, of a firm's actions regarding environmental and social criteria and in an expectation among stakeholders that they will play a more direct role in the creation of rules governing such measures.

In practice 
The OECD's "OECD Guidelines For The Regulation Of The Economic Development Of Certain Areas of Mexico" (the OECD/Mexico Guidelines) are an example of voluntary standards that reflect the requirements for fair trade to operate effectively. While they do not specifically establish a process for making fair trade decisions, they do include a requirement for countries to conduct periodic public reviews of fair trade practices in order to determine whether they are effectively enforced through adequate legal, institutional and educational mechanisms.

Similarly, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) has created a "Working Group on Fair Trade" that seeks to encourage countries to establish fair-trade measures similar to those outlined above through the use of technical assistance, capacity building, and knowledge exchange between nations. It also provides ongoing support for developing countries as they formulate national policies designed specifically for fair trading.

An example of fair trade standards being implemented in practice is the "Fairtrade Foundation" which was set up in 1991 by a coalition of UK retailers and consumers for the purpose of promoting fair trade practices in the domestic economy. It has since been joined by hundreds of companies and organizations all over Europe who produce and market what is described as ‚ÄúFairtrade Certified Products.‚Äù Examples of these products include:

 Coffee, cocoa, sugar, tea, and fruit juices made from ‚ÄúFairtrade Certified Coffee‚Äù.
 Chocolate made from ‚ÄúFairtrade certified cocoa‚Äù.
 Fairtrade cotton and organic cotton.
 ‚ÄúFairtrade tea‚Äù.
 Organic fruits and vegetables, including ‚ÄúFairtrade berries‚Äù
 Organic vegetables and nuts.
 Organic rice‚Äîa major export from Thailand to the Philippines.
 Organic sugar‚Äîmade by small-scale cane farmers in India.

To facilitate a fair trade deal, a commodity's price also needs to be negotiated before the transaction. Most major trading firms do this using two methods: an "offer" where the exporter provides a range of prices with an "ask" and also "bid" and "ask". The former is usually done when the firm has a good market position and the exporter must accept an offer. The latter is more common when a company has a relatively weak position and must request a price.

The "Fairtrade International Foundation" (formerly the "World Fair Trade Organization" or "WFO") is a non-profit, international trade organization that promotes fair labor conditions and other social criteria in the production of agricultural goods. The Fairtrade Foundation is also working to ensure that consumers, companies and governments are provided with "fair trade" options when making purchases.

Development and evolution 
The first fair-trade initiative was set up in 1971 by a group of British retailers and businesses as the "Fair Share Group". This was followed by the "Fair Trade Organization of Germany" (in 1975), the "Fair Trade Campaign of Holland" (1976), and the "Fair Trade Campaign of Austria" (in 19

It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.

instruction:
An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.

The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
output:
An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.

The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
20th-century Western classical music includes a diverse range of styles. From about 1900, some composers used new musical ideas to express their personal philosophies, world-views, and feelings. These so-called experimental composers used new musical instruments and technologies and created new sounds. They wrote unconventional forms of musical theatre, and experimental compositions. New techniques and technologies were incorporated into 20th-century forms including popular music, jazz, and electronic and popular dance music.

While some 20th-century music remained anchored in conventions of the past, many popular styles originated or coalesced in the 20th century. They included early examples of rock and roll (1930s), and most commonly, jazz, swing, bebop, salsa, country, blues, punk, rock, rhythm and blues, disco, hip hop and rap. Early hip hop and rap, popular in the 1970s and 1980s, became very influential in Western, African, and Latin music cultures. The electric guitar became widely used, and, in classical music, the use of electronic instruments became standard practice.

After the Second World War, music moved to new and emerging cities and venues. As the century progressed, it began to become highly commercialised in the West, where record profits and record loss led to consolidation of the music industry. In the U.S., many African-American musicians became a major influence on music, and the Harlem Renaissance, a blossoming of black art and culture, produced many important musicians, including the classic jazz performers and composers Duke Ellington and Charlie Parker. From the 1920s in the US, music genres such as swing, bebop, and rock and roll were developed. It was replaced by a genre known as rhythm and blues, which was further separated into R&B and pop by the beginning of the 1960s. Rock and roll was later transformed into 1960s and 1970s psychedelic rock, jazz fusion, hard rock, heavy metal, funk, and onward throughout the 1980s. After a surge of American popular music in the late 1980s known as the "Second British Invasion", a new wave of British acts gained popularity during the 1990s, which had a major effect on the U.S., as did U.S. techno in the early and mid-1990s.

With the arrival of the Internet, it became easy for independent artists to access markets to which they had no access before. This created new opportunities for artists, creating a significant change from the industrialization of music. The availability of streaming services such as Apple Music, Youtube Music, Spotify, SoundCloud has also enabled new music genres to thrive. Streaming services also allow for the discovery of new music, as well as the access to more genres than ever before. Additionally, it allows for more customization to individual listeners' interests, and more direct engagement with listeners. The advent of streaming services has resulted in the increased revenue of artists, but it has also resulted in less revenue for radio stations and major labels that are less digitalized than independent artists. However, radio has become more creative due to their lack of revenue and has increased the amount of advertising on radio since.

See also
 Music of the 20th century
 Music of the 21st century
 Timeline of music history

Notes

Further reading

 
 

 1950s
 1950s-related lists
1950s music by genre
1950s in music
 Music
20th century-related lists

Development studies is an interdisciplinary branch of social science. Development studies is offered as a specialized master's degree in a number of reputed universities around the world. It has grown in popularity as a subject of study since the early 1990s, and has been most widely taught and researched in developing countries and countries with a colonial history, such as the UK, where the discipline originated.  Students of development studies often choose careers in international organisations such as the United Nations, World Bank, non-governmental organisations (NGOs), media and journalism houses, private sector development consultancy firms, corporate social responsibility (CSR) bodies and research centers.
What are some popular careers for students of development studies?

International relations is the study of interactions between states, including relations between states and groups within states and other entities such as corporations, and the roles of states in global cooperation or multilateral organizations. International relations as a field is often categorized about whether it focuses on the interactions between states, on domestic politics, or even on international law.

What is international relations?
  
  
  
 

A.  Domestic Politics

B.  Relationships between states

C.  Law

Answer: B

2.1.1. Economic Growth
Read the following questions and the answer and complete the answers as shown.

The World Health Organization's Global Health Observatory estimates the average global life expectancy is 67.6 years in 2010. The global health burden of disease has been declining over the last 20 years.

The world continues to face enormous challenges to secure economic growth and development. How is economic growth defined?
  
  
  
 

A.  It is the change in quantity or quality of goods and services produced and distributed within a country.

B.  It measures the capacity to produce goods and services.

C.  It is used to measure how countries perform in comparison to each other or to world-average performance.

D.  It does not include the change brought about by trade.

Answer: A

Read the following question and the answer and complete the answers as shown.

The city of Harappa, in Punjab, which was discovered from excavating a site in 1921, was one early example of a civilization that dates back to 3400 BC.

What is the civilization of Harappa?
  
  
  
 

A.  The Indus Valley

B.  The Indus Valley Civilization

C.  The Harappan

D.  The Dravidian Civilization

Answer: B

4.1.1. Environment
Read the following question and the answer and complete the answers as shown.
The current situation on the world's air quality can be characterized as follows

2 billion of the 7 billion people on Earth live in areas of air pollution that are considered 'poor'.

8 million people die each year from air quality, which is equal to 17 percent of deaths worldwide. This makes air pollution the fifth leading cause of death after tobacco, high blood pressure, high blood glucose and high cholesterol.

Air Quality Indices are used to report the overall pollution level of local environment with many countries adopting the Air Quality Index, AQI, or the Air Pollution Index, API.

For urban air quality assessments, the AQI system is the preferred measure of overall health risk due to exposure to air pollution in different parts of the world.

What is the air pollution world has currently?
  
  
  
 

A.  10 percent of deaths worldwide.

B.  17 percent of deaths worldwide.

C.  2 billion of the 7 billion people on Earth.

D.  8 million people per year.

Answer: C

Design a syllabus for the given course. Students should be given a list of the chapters with brief explanations of each chapter's purpose.

Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)
output:
Design a syllabus for the given course. Students should be given a list of the chapters with brief explanations of each chapter's purpose.

Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python)

by <NAME> and <NAME>

This text will introduce students to the main fundamentals of programming in Python. Python is a programming language that is popular among engineers and computer scientists. It is user-friendly, fast, and easy to learn.

### Introduction

The first part of the text will explain the basic concepts students need to know to begin writing code. Python is a programming language, but it is also more than that. Python is an interpreted language which makes the writing of code more efficient and allows students to try out programs on the computer with relative ease. This part of the text will begin with an introduction to programming in Python.

This will be followed by a discussion of the basics of functions, classes, and data. The use of data types is at the center of all programming, and is fundamental to the development of more complex code.

The second part of the course will introduce students to more complex programming techniques, starting with a discussion of data structures and how they are used. This will be followed by a discussion of loops, lists, and strings.

The third part of the curriculum will begin by introducing students to the basics of databases and database-driven pages. The course will then move onto an introduction to Python Web Frameworks, such as Django and Flask, which will give students a foundation on which to build more in-depth knowledge.

### Syllabus

### Course Intro

Introduction to Python programming

Why Python?

Python has a large user

community

Python is easy to start

Python is popular among engineers

Python is easy to read
  
Python is widely used in scientific domains (e.g., astronomy, physics, mathematics,
and finance)
  
Python is easy to extend

Introduction to data structures

An overview of the basics of data

The three different abstract data types

the object oriented abstraction

The importance of data structures

Data Structure Classes and Objects

Social Media Marketer

_Social media is a key part of our lives. It is a source we can use to keep in touch with loved ones and friends. Social media also is a great tool that businesses can use to advertise and market their products and services. Have you ever been on Facebook and clicked on a link and then a video begins, but you never finished watching it? You weren't trying to watch a video, but it started playing because the video was included in a blog site that you had been reading. Social media is all around us, with a variety of ways to use it for marketing. If you have some idea of ways that social media can be utilized, and some knowledge about social media, you can easily become a job for today!_

### SOCIAL MEDIA MARKETING PERSONALITY TRAITS

  Don't try to be all things to all people.

  Use the tools provided.

  Develop a professional site rather than one based on free Web sites.

  Network and meet as many people as possible so you can learn and grow.

  Be flexible and adaptive.

  Don't take things personally when customers criticize you or post negative comments.

  Develop your product or service to make it as special or memorable as possible.

If you have these personality traits, you definitely have the qualities that are needed to market a product or service. You can become a marketing professional quickly, because you already have many of the tools necessary from your day-to-day life as a consumer. People who possess these personality traits will quickly be placed on a job, and more are needed all the time!

Employment of social media marketers is projected to grow 5 percent from 2014 to 2024, about as fast as the average for all occupations. Social media marketers use social networking sites and other online media to help businesses and charities connect with existing or potential customers.

### Have Fun!

Social media marketers help businesses and charities use social networking sites and other online media to connect with existing and potential customers. instruction:
Come up with the courses that one is supposed to take in order to be an expert in a given field.

Graphic Design
output:
Come up with the courses that one is supposed to take in order to be an expert in a given field.

Graphic Design

Computer Programming

Film

Business

Marketing

Advertising

And so on...

But this list is incomplete because it doesn't include the real essence of what it means to be a creative person. Although these specific areas and occupations are important to many people, the person that creates will find a way to contribute whatever is needed at the time it is needed. What makes a true creative creative?

1. Passion

To develop their craft, creatives have to love what they do. Creativity is only of value if it applies to something we believe in, if it resonates with us, and if it comes from our center of truth.

This is the same motivation most people will find when we are doing what we love.

So, what do we love? We can do anything we like, and we can love anything we do. Some people like music, some people like writing, some people like painting.

For me it takes some work to find what I want to be passionate about. All my life I wanted to be a professional guitar player, so at the beginning of my career I did nothing but practice. But I soon realized that this was the wrong way to go about it. I had to love what I did (and this comes from the place of truth). So, after I had been playing for about 3 years at a local club, I heard other guitarists and found that what I was doing wasn't good enough. I needed to change what I was doing. The most important thing I learned in this situation was that I needed to let go and let God (a phrase you'll hear a lot later on in this book) guide me.

2. Freedom

Creatives do not do what they do to make money or to be the most successful in any way. They are the ones who choose where to spend their energy. This is one of the greatest freedoms we have as artists, since it is a choice that we have never been limited by.

Most of us have jobs that involve paying bills, etc. In order to be able to pay those bills, we must take on other people's opinions and we often have to compromise to the point where we are unhappy with what we are doing.

For us, it is the complete opposite.

What we can do to support our creative endeavors is limit the number of people that are involved. The more people there are getting in the way, the less time and energy we'll have available. And if we have less time and energy available, then it will be much harder to create what we are excited about.

Many creatives find that they are happier and more valuable to the world if they can live on very limited incomes. This does not make sense to a lot of people, however; I think we need to remember that this is not their primary value. What they are trying to do is contribute and that is what is important. It's kind of like the person who wants to become a professional athlete. They play this game as an opportunity to be recognized for having a passion for something and to inspire others. Not to make money, but to be the best at what they do.

3. The World

Our biggest asset is the world. This may seem strange to some people since most of us spend all of our time trying to get rid of certain things, but to the creative, the world is the one thing that gives us purpose and it is the source of infinite possibilities. The more aware we are of the world and its possibilities, the more valuable and powerful we become.

Without this appreciation and ability to see, we become stuck with our preconceived mindsets and we can't change. If we want to create something with real value, however, we need to get as aware as possible of everything we encounter.

We need to make sure our perspective is global.

When we go walking in the forest, we need to see everything we pass and, when we come back, see everything we have passed through from inside out again while lying in bed at night. This may sound a little strange to some people, but doing this can really help us get connected to the part of us that wants to create. If the trees that we passed by had a part to play in our creation, then we need to have this part of us.

4. Imagination

Creativity is a big part of everything that a human does, so we need to remember that when we come up against any of our limitations. Once we realize that we have to create, we need to remember that we are not limited.

Our creative imagination is a powerful tool but we often get caught with preconceived notions of what's possible.

We can get

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output:
Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
What is the best question to ask? You can ask yourself this question before you begin presenting: What is the best possible question you can think of? A great question will drive the lesson forward. It will help you move to the next thing, and your students may be more interested in the answer.
The more you read and listen to others, the better your presentation will be. For example, if you are going to talk about the history of medicine in the United States, listen to the newscast.
Students, if you have been listening to presentations all your life, you‚Äôre probably tired of that! Presentations that are too long are boring because not everyone wants to hear all of the information.
If you have two or three big things to talk about, divide those up into separate points and present at the end what you have already talked about.
When you have finished a presentation, check your notes. What are the things on your list that you did not talk about? If your notes include the name of the person you are speaking about, and you forgot to say it, it will cause you to do what? Look up!
Be careful of this mistake because it is easy to make.
To be effective in a presentation, you must be friendly with your audience. If you don‚Äôt think you are friendly, practice being friendly with everyone you meet. Remember how people interact with you when you are friendly. They will smile and laugh.
Have you ever been in a school or public place that was not very warm? Most of us have, and we feel uncomfortable.
Just as you would turn your room or building into a very warm place, you would do this with your presentation.
For example, if you wanted something to make you feel nice, what would you do? If it were me, I‚Äôd get a big bag of M&M‚Äôs from a candy store and eat them all.
Do you imagine that you‚Äôre as cute as Tweety Bird? You probably are, because you are much cuter. You‚Äôve been watching too much television. What are some things you can do to make you look cute? When you‚Äôre alone, laugh at yourself! When you do a laugh-to yourself, it makes your face look different. You probably have a double chin.
In business meetings, everyone in the room should be involved in the discussion. If it is a meeting of teachers, everyone must also be involved in the discussion, because those who are not in the room are not responsible for what is going on.
Even so, you have to have a good attitude about it. No matter what you think you should say, you have to ask if there is anyone else who has anything to say. Then listen to what they have to say. You can‚Äôt do all the talking. If there are any other people who want to talk, they have as much right to speak as you do.
In a recent study, when students were asked to evaluate their best presentation, they ranked ‚Äúwarm greeting, smile, and open body language‚Äù as the most important aspects of their presentation.
This tells us two important things. First, you must be friendly. You can make your students more comfortable by smiling at them. Smile, and smile broadly because it makes you appear more sincere. Then, make eye contact because smiling with your eyes helps warm the audience.
Second, and most important, you must learn to speak in a friendly manner. If you are not very good at it, be comfortable and happy with yourself. You know that you are not a professional.
When you are ready, you think you are ready. When they don‚Äôt notice you or look at you, you can talk about yourself.
As a professional, you are not really an expert. You have to know a lot of things, but you are not the expert.
This is important because if you know a lot but you don‚Äôt know how to express yourself or how to teach, you are not an expert. Experts use their brains to make their presentations work. They don‚Äôt just know what they have to say. They have to be able to say it in a friendly manner.

instruction: You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps:
output:
You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps:
Recycle Christmas trees. Trees can become a very expensive disposal option if you don‚Äôt recycle them. If you live in a place where Christmas trees are burned, consider donating your tree or have it shredded for use as mulch. If you live in a place where they‚Äôre not burned, recycling is usually available, and you can sell your tree to a reseller. This is an excellent way to save some money and to help the environment. If you live in an area that is not open to recycling Christmas trees, find out about the different options you can use to dispose of your tree and help the environment.
Compost. When you compost your holidays this way, you use all the holiday materials you need to create the perfect composting garden. Your trash bag gets turned into nutrients that you can use to nourish other plants. You can leave out the trash bag and set out the compost bucket. This way, you can start right away with your compost.
Create your holidays yourself. One of the best ways to save on your energy use is by not buying any holiday gifts. Instead, make your own gifts. Your friends and family will love that you‚Äôre making an effort to save money and to help the environment. Just make sure that the gifts are handmade, not homemade. You can also create homemade toys for your children or animals to play with or homemade household items for you to use around the house. In addition, you can make your own ornaments or use recycled materials (such as newspaper or metal ornaments) to create your own gift decorations.
Eat homemade. When you create your holiday meals yourself, you can make sure that you‚Äôre using organic and sustainable foods. Cooking takes a lot less energy when your food is unprocessed, especially if you grow and harvest the food yourself. In addition, by using organic and sustainable foods, you‚Äôre helping to decrease the amount of pesticides and hormones that you and your family consume. By not eating meat, you‚Äôre also decreasing the amount of grain and grain byproducts.
Go electric. Instead of using paper, you could use one of the new power-based or electronic options for your cards and mementos. With these, you just print out the card on your computer and print directly on the box. If you aren‚Äôt a printer or you prefer to make your cards by hand, you can hand write them and print them on plain white paper. You can buy postcards or have a family member hand make the postcard.
Buy second hand. Since your gifts will come from handmade or recycled sources, you can also think about buying gifts that have been previously owned. These are a great way to help you and your family and friends save on your gifts.
Cut down on buying additional holiday items. You can cut down and reduce on your electric bill by reducing the amount you use in your new ornaments, lights, tree, decorations, ornaments, and so on. If you‚Äôre not ready to give up your tree, consider cutting it back a bit or replacing it with a pine tree. If you‚Äôre willing to give up your tree altogether, you can opt for some lights around your windows or candles instead. In general, the most energy-efficient decorations are the ones that don‚Äôt have too much decoration and are kept on a timer that‚Äôs turned off at midnight. With this option, you always know when it‚Äôs time to turn on your lights. These timers can even be used for your outside lights.
When you turn on your lights, unplug them and turn them off when you‚Äôre done using them. This will help to save your electricity while you‚Äôre using the lights. You also won‚Äôt be using unnecessary power to keep the lights on.
In addition, when you‚Äôre unplugging your decorations, don‚Äôt keep them plugged into the outlet. Instead, bring their cords with you. You can then plug them into your regular outlet when you‚Äôre ready to turn them on and off. This can also help you keep from burning down your house from an overloaded outlet or from other accidents this way.
These are the perfect way for you to make sure you‚Äôre spending a few dollars to make an impact on the environment. These practices can make holiday planning so much more eco-friendly. You won‚Äôt feel guilty when you spend so little on your holiday and you can pass the holiday savings on to other people you want to give gifts to. Just make sure that you‚Äôre recycling, composting, and buying second hand and homemade wherever possible.

instruction:
There are many creative projects we can build at home that are related to the given theme, so let's list some of them.

Theme: Circuits
output:
There are many creative projects we can build at home that are related to the given theme, so let's list some of them.

Theme: Circuits / LEDs

## 1 Connect a circuit to an LED

If your kids are too young to use soldering, or you have no experience with circuits, use this approach. It has a few advantages:

  *   You don't have to worry about the wire going through the soldering iron. Kids can easily connect the wire to a LED themselves.

  *   No soldering! You only need to connect two wires with copper tape with a wire in the middle.

  *   You don't need any technical skills, so you can build circuits together from the beginning.

  *   You can still use soldering. For example, you can connect the wires with tape yourself before your child's birthday party and show them their circuit on the big LED board.

### Parts

  *   Circuit board, such as these 3V LEDs (you can also use 5V LEDs, in which case you need a regulator)

  *   LED (for the 3V circuits you need, you can use the smaller 3V or even 1.2V LEDs like this)

  *   Wire

  *  copper tape (you can also use copper wire to connect to the LED ‚Äì this is important to prevent a shock)

### Steps

  1.  [+] To connect the wires to the circuit you can use tape, as shown below.

  2.  [+] Or connect the LEDs directly using a wire. Then you can use the tape on each wire to cover the wire end.

  3.  [+] Your circuit is now finished ‚Äì you can insert it into the big LED board.

  4.  [+] Let's build more advanced circuits.

## 2 Build a circuit with 3 LEDs

### Parts

  *   Circuit board, such as this 3V circuit for LEDs

  *   Copper tape

  *   Wire

### Steps

  1.   [+] Connect the wire to the LEDs on the circuit board.

  2.  [+] Your circuit is now finished ‚Äì you can insert it into the big LED board as a stand-alone circuit.

  3.  [+] Of course, you can connect more wires to the circuit. For example, you can connect the LEDs in different colors or different circuits.

## 3 Build an LED flash with an IR emitter

We'll use these two parts again:

  *   IR emitter

  *   3V LED

### Parts

  *   Circuit board, such as this 3V circuit for LEDs

  *   Copper tape

  *   3V LED

  *   IR emitter

### Steps

  1.   [+] On the circuit board there are three sockets for the LEDs in different colors. Connect the IR emitter to socket C.

  2.  [+] Connect your flashlight to socket A, and the LED to socket B.

  3.  [+] The circuit is now finished ‚Äì you can insert it into the big LED display and turn it on. What do you think you'll see?

## 4 Make a circuit with two LEDs and two switches

### Parts

  *   Circuit board

  *   Two LEDs such as these 5V LEDs

  *   Copper tape

  *   Two switch switches

### Steps

  1.  [+] Connect two circuit boards in series as shown below.

  2.  [+] Connect a wire from each LED to one of the switches ‚Äì like this LED for the first switch and the other LED for the second.

  3.  [+] Connect a wire from each switch to the other switch ‚Äì like this 1, 0 switch.

  4.   [+] Your circuit is now finished ‚Äì you can insert it into the big LED display.

## 5 Build a circuit with 10 LEDs

The next circuit will build on the ones you've previously built; we'll connect more circuits to the last one. As usual, we'll use these parts:

  *   Circuit board, such as these 3V LEDs

  *   Copper tape

  *   Wire

  *   LED

### Parts

  *   Circuit board, such as this 3V circuit for LEDs

instruction:
Make a list of the materials that will be required to build the given tool.

Coffee Darkness Meter
output:
Make a list of the materials that will be required to build the given tool.

Coffee Darkness Meter
=====================

This is a tool kit containing two parts:

  1. The cup the coffee is measured in.
  2. An analog meter that measures coffee darkness.

The main part is a 3" cube, made from 1/4" plywood. This is the base on which the entire coffee cup will be placed,
and the location of the hole for the ananlog meter.
The size is large enough that the base won't be in the way of the measurement.

The second part is a brass meter that's 5 3/16" tall, 4" across at the widest point, and has a radius of 2"
in the middle of the bar.
On the top it will be a round hole of exactly 2".

The black color of the "meter" is to match the black color of the cup.

Building Instructions for Cup
----------------------------

This step is optional, but the result will give you an attractive, sturdy cup.

Measure out all of the cut material (4" squares, 2-5/8" squares, 1/8" x 2" strips) using your scale for the final size.

Assemble the 2 4" squares into a square that is exactly 8-5/8" on a side, and
assemble the 2 2-5/8 squares into a square that is exactly 8" on a side

Assemble the sides of the box using the 1-8" squares. You will end up using one of the strips on every side.

The sides of the box will be 4-1/8" tall, 4 7/8" wide, and have an aperture that is 3-5/8" across in the middle.

Drill a hole in the middle of the top of the box, with a diameter of 2-1/4".

Now you are ready to glue the interior parts together.

Put the interior parts inside the box, and make sure everything is centered.
Gently place the box on a flat surface, and put a few ounces of weight on the inside.
When you put weight on the top, it should be quite heavy.
When you put weight on the middle (between the "fingers"), the sides should "climb" up.
If that does not happen, then it is not centered.

Doing it this way, you will be able to adjust the height
of the cup until it is the correct height for all of your favorite coffees.

When it is centered, start gluing. There are no real rules except to make a smooth, sturdy result.
But one thing to watch out for is to use very short glue  sprays, and to apply glue to your work carefully.

Once it is done, do not put a lid or something else on it until it's completely dry. Let it dry for a week or more.
This gives it extra strength. If you finish it before it's completely dry, it will be more liable to wobble.

Cup Construction Materials
--------------------------

Plywood
   8 4" squares
12 2 2-5/8" squares
   2 5/8" strips

Brass
   5 5/8" square
2 2 1/8" rectangles

Anvil
   1 1 1/8" square

Lap joints
   8 1/8"-2" squares

Glue
   Two-part wood glue

Building Instructions for Meter
-------------------------------

The meter for the darkness meter is an unbent pipe that is 1 1/8" in diameter.

First, cut off the 2 1/8" end of the 1 1/8" pipe.
This will create a 4" long section of pipe that is 1 1/8" in diameter, and a 2" end that's round.

Next, you will have to bend it.
First, wrap your pipe so that the 2" end is on one side.
Then measure in several different orientations, from the 2" end, to the 4" end,
  and find the point where the curve is closest to a right angle.
This is the "true" opening of

instruction:
Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.

Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
output:
Provide a detailed explanation of the steps that are required in order to construct the given project.

Steam Engine Using an Empty Beer Can
===================================

A steam engine provides a lot of useful energy, and it is useful for many kinds of things such as cooking food, heating your home, and washing floors or clothes. In this project, you will use a basic steam engine as the basis for creating a cooking device.

When you heat up water to a boil, you use a lot of energy in order to do so. Instead, turn this problem upside down: instead of using energy to heat some water up, use energy to cool this water. That way, the steam engine can provide energy to cook your food!

In order to cook your food, there are a few things that you need to do. Firstly, place your food into a container. This can be as simple as a plastic bag. If you put your food in this container, place a lid on top of it. The container should then be placed into some water, and let sit for several minutes. Use a thermometer to check that the water has reached a temperature of about 80 degrees Celsius.

At this point, all the water turns into steam in your container. When this happens, the steam will go out of the bottom of the bag (or the lid) and enter a funnel pipe. This pipe in turn is plugged into your steam engine. As the steam passes through the engine, that engine begins to vibrate. Then, that vibration is converted via a speaker into a loud sound.

In order for the vibrations to generate any useful food-cooking energy, there are two pieces of equipment which you need to use. The first piece are two plywood wedges which sit inside your funnel. These wedges are intended to hold the food into your container as they are vibrating (See Figure 10.1 for an example of these wedges. You can use cardboard or wood wedges to hold your food while it is being vibrated.)

Figure 10.1. A picture of a steam engine that is being used for cooking.

The second piece of equipment is a metal bucket that is held in place using two rubber bands. This bucket sits upside down on one side of a pot and contains some ground coffee beans. When the bucket inside of this pot is vibrated hard enough, the beans that are inside the bucket will be able to grind themselves into a fine powder. This process happens very quickly.

In order for your steam engine to vibrate as hard as it can, you will need to attach some kind of sound amplifier. The simplest amplifier that you can do is one that works via a rubber band and a wooden paddle. You can find this kind of amplifier in many of the toys that you find for children. Place a rubber band across your paddle, and place two of your plywood wedges onto one of the ends of your paddle. Use the other end of the rubber band to attach the bucket to your paddle.

At this point, you can stand your steam engine up vertically or horizontally. Make sure that your funnel opens down into a vertical position and your steam pipe ends up above your steam engine. Then, bring a kettle of water down to a boil and place it next to where the steam pipe enters into the steam engine. After a few minutes, attach your speaker to the bottom of your steam engine just as you have seen in the picture. Then, put a bag of dry, non-dairy ice cubes in the water bath. After about five minutes, you are ready to start the vibrations to get your food cooked.

The first time that you run this experiment, you will hear a steady kind of high-pitched sound. This sound is the result of the steam escaping from the top of the funnel pipe. This sound should be heard until the water has gone completely cold and become solid ice. When you hear the sound start to go away, insert the bag of ice cubes. When these are fully dissolved, you will hear a louder kind of high-pitched sound. This sound is the result of your steam engine now vibrating.

The problem with this first attempt is that it may make it too difficult to hear what is going on. The second attempt is a little better: you can run the experiment using an empty beer can.

Empty Beer Can as a Steam Engine
=================================

Since the beer cans that you can buy today are plastic or aluminum, your steam engine will not work with that material. You might be able to work with a

instruction:
Estimate the cost of supplies required to create the given project and calculate the total cost.

DIY Water Chiller
Required items are: Ice-maker, Icebox/cooler, Temperature regulator, Aquarium pump x2, 12V power supply
output:
Estimate the cost of supplies required to create the given project and calculate the total cost.

DIY Water Chiller
Required items are: Ice-maker, Icebox/cooler, Temperature regulator, Aquarium pump x2, 12V power supply, and 12 volt 40 amp fuse block. Calculations on the website say it may cost as much as $130. This project is similar to one I did but it doesn't need to contain a refrigerator. I made this water chiller for an aquarium set-up. There are other chiller types such as 3-2 chiller (ice machine + 2 separate water chillers) as well but I haven't created any yet.

DIY Cooling Pack
Required items are: 5-18v 3-4amp fan, 3 18v 50-100 amp DC motors, 50W - 180W 12v thermo element, 3w high intensity leds, 5-12v DC relay, 12v power supply w/ fuse, 3x1000ma batteries, a couple of switches, a few connectors, and a bit of cable.

AquaTech Cooling Systems Cooler
Required items are: Temperature regulator, 240w AC fan, 24V 600W Peltier plate, fan controller, 12v regulator w/ fuse, motor controller w/ 3dip switch, and 12V 6amp power supply. Calculations on the website say it may cost as much as $350. It is similar to the AquaCooling System that I've also used and made. The idea of this is to make a cooler for your tank but not just to create one that would cool the whole tank. It needs to cool your tank but the rest of your system is to be made with other parts.

DIY 3-2 Chiller
Required items: Aquarium pump x 2, Temperature regulator, Ice-maker, 12v regulator w/ fuse, 12v power supply, and 12 volt 40 amp fuse block. I made one of these but it can't operate because it keeps catching on the aquarium's water and has a tendency to fall off the ice-maker. It was basically a tank-mounted fan and two aquarium pumps which helped move the air in and out of the tank. I had them each with own regulator to have the flow rate from each pump be controlled. In the middle was the controller and temperature/ice-maker. There were three switches (two for the pumps and one for the regulator) and one fuse.

DIY Aquarium Chiller
Required items are: Aquarium pump x2, Temperature regulator, Ice-maker, and 12v regulator w/ fuse. I made this for an aquarium set-up and only the temperature regulator and ice-maker were used. The idea of this coolant was to have a pump at the top of the tank with a hole in the bottom wall where the controller was located. It used a fan at the entrance to the tank to blow in air and a temperature regulator to let the temperature in or out as it needed to.

DIY Air Conditioning System

Required items: 2 12v 800w Peltier plates, water cooler controller, water cooler fan controller, 12v regulator w/ fuse, two 12v 9-18v thermo element switches, 12v power supply w/ fuse, switches, and connectors. I made this for an aquarium set-up. The idea of this coolant was to have a pump at the entrance of the tank with a small water cooler at the top, a few fans, and a controller. The water cooler was used to control the temperature inside the enclosure. I use my thermostat at work to take readings. The water cooler was the main component as it controlled the temperature. It did well until I decided that I needed to increase/decrease the water cooler's capacity. Since the water cooler controller would only function for a water cooler of 65/96 degrees and it was designed primarily for aquariums, I had to find a better way to have the controller detect the temperature. I thought of how my thermostat at works which works by having a temp sensor which is set at a specific temperature and a change in the amount of energy the thermostat needs to put out to keep the temperature constant. By adding a thermo element switch at the head of the tank water cooler, I can increase or decrease the amount of energy it takes to hold the temperature because it will be based on the temperature and not have to do the math for each individual switch.

Cool

instruction:
Answer the following literature question as accurately as possible based on your knowledge of literature for high school students.

What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?
output:
Answer the following literature question as accurately as possible based on your knowledge of literature for high school students.

What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?

______________________________________

 **Chapter 5**

**Growth**

**The Growth of Sisyphus**

Greek philosopher Heraclitus is often quoted as saying, "The only constant is change." A simple saying, but it seems to hold true for all things‚Äîthe world around us and our own bodies. This chapter explores physical and emotional growth and the role of the parent and teacher in guiding the student to that growth.

### **Chapter Learning Objectives**

  Understand a student's physical and intellectual development

  Understand the role of the educator and the way they can help students grow

  Evaluate how to best support students with emotional and intellectual challenges, based on the principles outlined in this chapter

  Evaluate how to best support students with physical and emotional challenges, based on the principles outlined in this chapter

### **Physical and Emotional Development**

### **Student Learning**

This chapter focuses on the physical development of students in the K‚Äì12 environment. This covers the cognitive, emotional, and social growth of students and how students reach certain milestones in their life. In each state, students meet certain milestones, depending on the grade range that they are in. For example, fifth-, sixth-, and seventh-grade students must meet certain physical requirements to participate in team sports. All students are required to wear a helmet while playing team sports by the time third grade rolls around, unless they are working on a modified sport or activity. A student's physical development is not only a prerequisite to getting in the game, but it is also an indicator of health and learning development. For example, a student must have basic motor skills to write, which means that the student must be able to sit upright while working. This can cause challenges for some students who have physical challenges.

**WHAT ARE A CHILD'S MORAL AND SOCIAL REVGULS?**

> They consist in the habit of doing right.... Our moral feelings are nothing but our natural affections.... But, as our affections advance, and as our senses become more acute, so our affections become more extensive and refined.

‚ÄîImmanuel Kant

In addition to their physical development, children must learn to develop as moral, civil, and social individuals. Social development starts with the family and teachers at home and school. A child's moral development begins at the age of five and progresses throughout life (see Figure 5.1).

**FIGURE 5.1. A Child's Moral Development  
(Courtesy of OpenStax, _Principles of Psychology_ by Roy R. Griggs [CC BY 3.0], via Wikimedia Commons)**

_Source:_ OpenStax, _Principles of Psychology_ by Roy R. Griggs [CC BY 3.0], via Wikimedia Commons

A child's social development is based on the way others treat that child. Sometimes, children with special needs may find themselves the butt of the jokes of their peers or may be left out of the mainstream activities of their school. What are they supposed to do? Do they join in with their peers, or do they stay away from them? How does or should someone with Asperger's Syndrome, for example, react to these circumstances? There is no right answer. Children must learn on their own how to deal with these circumstances or with others who may be mean to them.

Children learn and advance as moral and social beings from two sources: the family and the peer group. Each child is nurtured by different family and peers. Some children may have a very supportive family and a good circle of friends who are sensitive and caring. Sometimes children have to learn how to deal with negative situations at home, or they may be teased and bullied at school by their classmates. These occurrences in a child's life shape that child into the adult he or she will later become.

### **Parents as a Learning Environment**

Many students are not fortunate enough to have parents who want them to succeed or understand what they need, and these students struggle in school and at home‚Äîand they often do not progress beyond the classroom.

In fact, it is very difficult for students with special needs to get and retain the kind of help they need and need at home. There often is a sense of hopelessness among these students because nothing seems to happen when they try to ask for help so they begin to lose their motivation. This often becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy for them, leaving them uninterested and disinterested in their schooling and their personal lives.

If a student with a disability

instruction: Give me an idea of the mental exercises you do to inspire yourself.
output:
Give me an idea of the mental exercises you do to inspire yourself.
I have always been an avid reader and still am and in my case I have to say there have been some very different books, but my favorites are biographies. I love reading about people and I think they inspired me to be open-minded and to see things from many different perspectives. To this day I‚Äôm still trying to understand myself and find peace with the fact that I don‚Äôt know everything. It‚Äôs like putting your puzzle together. I like the mystery that comes with that. I‚Äôve always loved watching movies, especially musicals, so that has always been a big part of my life as well. It takes me on a journey that I can identify with or in the way I see life ‚Äì a lot of life is like that.
Which book are you reading right now?
There are so many good books out there. What I‚Äôm reading right now I think is very inspirational and amazing is, ‚ÄúUnbroken‚Äù.
What role does music play in your life?
I was listening to music since I can remember. It is a big part of my life. I listen to music on a daily basis. Music is like food to me, I have to have it. It‚Äôs part of culture and is universal as well. It‚Äôs amazing. It‚Äôs just a part of who I am. It‚Äôs an addiction to me. It‚Äôs like a therapy for me in a way.
What music would you say has been an influence on you?
I think we all come from different places but I think all of us feel music in different ways. We all have different backgrounds and we all feel it in different ways. It‚Äôs a universal language, I would hope. All kinds of different stuff‚Ä¶ I also sing classical music and I love playing a concerto. It‚Äôs not only rock ‚Äòn roll or punk rock. It‚Äôs very different.
To follow up on your last question, if you had to pick any three artists to have on a desert island what artists would you pick?
It‚Äôs such a difficult question.
Alicia Keys, Prince, Madonna
Your first album ‚ÄúUnder the Big Orange Sky‚Äù came out in 2010. What do you think was the best song from the first album?
I think ‚ÄúGone‚Äù is one of my favorite songs on the album. It‚Äôs a cover song but we put our own little spin on it. We decided to bring the song back to life because it‚Äôs a 90s song that everyone has heard and everyone has a connection to it. We tried to do a cover where we could put an acoustic spin on it and tried to capture that spirit; I really think it turned out great.
What are you working on now?
We put together a very cool album and I would really like to talk about that. We are very pleased and excited to have the new album ‚ÄúInto the Black‚Äù. It‚Äôs the first album I‚Äôve put out that‚Äôs truly a collection of songs I can say that I wrote by myself. It‚Äôs a very unique story and I think everyone who listens to the album will be able to attach themselves to a particular song.
What was it like going into the Blackhouse to record your album?
It‚Äôs definitely something new for me. I was so glad that I chose Blackhouse because I think this album will make us more famous; everyone will know us. It wasn‚Äôt just anyone making this album. It was Blackhouse and they have this wonderful history of music. The studio and everything about it‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs like a castle and it‚Äôs made of wood. It‚Äôs very quiet. Just being there is almost like being in a museum. We all had a lot of fun. It was a very good experience, very good.
What was it like working with your brothers and sisters?
It‚Äôs been like nothing else is going to come after that. My brothers and sisters are the best thing to go with. I have four brothers and three sisters and I think we all get along really well and even though we grew up being separated by some time and our parents split up, but we make it work. Being apart for a while is fine. We each did the same. It was nothing new. We had great childhood and now it‚Äôs a great family.
Do those childhood memories come out when you‚Äôre writing music?
Some of my songs are about things that happened in my childhood. For example, ‚ÄúGone‚Äù was about my grandfather who passed away in Jamaica from cancer. I was there and I wanted to dedicate that song to him. I think about my grandfather and my grandmother. It‚Äôs a very touching song and I think that was very special to all of us. Every time we remember something, we would tell each other, ‚ÄúWe have to write a song about this

instruction:
In relation to the given weather scenario, give some tips on how to adjust the travel plans with it.

a sudden temperature change
output:
In relation to the given weather scenario, give some tips on how to adjust the travel plans with it.

a sudden temperature change might ruin your plan 
you must take into 
considerations the climate of the places where you plan to go first and for the duration of the entire trip 

A: The sentence given cannot be the answer to the question.
"Weather is an effect of climate", says here:


*

*"weather" refers to the particular climate that we are experiencing right now, i.e. what we can observe;

*"climate" refers to the natural characteristics of a place (the place being in this case the whole globe) over extended periods of time (usually 30 years).


Therefore, an expression like "a sudden temperature change might ruin your plan" would not be a sufficient advice to an expat about how to overcome a climate-related problem with his travel plans.
"Give some tips on how to adjust the travel plans with it."
In the past tense "It" refers to the problem to be solved. As the given sentence does not mention or give any advice on how to solve or deal with the problem, it is not possible to use here (just from a linguistic point of view).


*

*The problem to be solved is a sudden temperature change 

*The problem to be solved could ruin your plan 

*It should adjust the travel plans with the given weather scenario (that is the problem to be solved).

instruction:
