instruction: What if the Internet had been invented during the Renaissance period?
output:
What if the Internet had been invented during the Renaissance period?
The Internet, in brief, is a set of computer networks that interlink multiple network regions and allow data to be exchanged quickly and reliably. It allows us to transmit all kinds of media ‚Äî text, voice, images, etc. ‚Äî in different parts of the world. The Internet is currently run by dozens of ‚ÄúISPs,‚Äù or Internet service providers.
The history of the Internet is divided into four phases. In the pre-Internet period, computer networks were run by organizations: governments, universities, research institutes, etc. Then, during the 1970s and 1980s, several ‚ÄúARPANETs‚Äù were operated all over the world by governments. These ARPANETs were connected by multiple phone lines. The second phase took place between 1983 and 1987, when researchers started developing algorithms and protocols to interconnect several networks.
The third phase took place between 1990 and 1996, when the Internet expanded rapidly. Many countries started building their own computer networks. Many of these still do not have access to the Internet. Finally, in the fourth and current phase, new generations of Internet users have started to participate in the process of web creation. Over twenty years have passed since then, and the Internet now links several billion users.
However, many people believe that the Internet had been invented way before the 1990s. One of them is the Renaissance artist Michelangelo, who died in the middle of the sixteenth century. During his lifetime, he was the most famous artist in the world and left behind the celebrated Statue of David.
Michelangelo is known for designing his canvasses at great speed, and for experimenting with new techniques. He often changed his original work and made many changes ‚Äî especially during the final painting phase ‚Äî and so he ended up with hundreds of unused canvasses and designs. During his lifetime, Michelangelo gave these to his friends.
One of the friends was the Renaissance architect and sculptor Donato Bramante. Donato is the man who designed the first Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica in Rome. Later he went on to be a general architect for King of France Francis I and designed the grand Sala Regia in the Vatican and the church of Saint Denis. The French king sent him to Rome to find Michelangelo‚Äôs unfinished canvasses.
Bramante took a look at the canvasses and was shocked to discover that they weren‚Äôt simply unfinished work. Instead, in many cases, they contained blueprints for the design of Internet computer networks. Many of the projects, which Michelangelo designed, contained the names of the countries to which they were destined. In some of them, there are even names of their potential users.
In fact, Michelangelo is known to have studied military networks in order to design these canvasses, and since he is also known to have been an enemy of the Catholic church, it is likely that he used these designs as part of his anti-Catholic campaign. The network in this case is called ‚ÄúL‚ÄôInsubria‚Äù, which means ‚ÄúThe Desert‚Äù, and was probably designed as a reference to the ‚ÄúGreat Deserts‚Äù Michelangelo created (which were a series of canvasses of desolate landscapes, depicting a bleak and uninhabited world). This network was going to be operated by Catholic countries, which were going to link them to the country where Michelangelo was the head of computer programming.
One of the canvasses depicts a large pyramid with several computer networks connected to it. Others are simply maps of computer networks. Other canvases depict the actual operating of some of these networks, and even show their names.
There are also canvasses in which Michelangelo showed different computer networks together, as well as the names of various countries and their respective languages. In fact, one of the canvasses even showed the world map he drew before he died.
The only thing that Michelangelo did not include in any of his canvasses is any link to the actual Internet, which is strange, because Internet data is being transmitted via computers and computers are basically networks, and that‚Äôs why we currently live in the Internet age. Maybe Michelangelo never did include this part of his project, or maybe he just forgot.
But the most interesting thing is that these canvasses exist in France at a time when the Internet didn‚Äôt exist at all. French King Francis I was ruling the country during the Renaissance, and no one even considered the possibility of sending messages across the globe using electrical signals.
In fact, even today, few people believe Internet has been invented even during the Renaissance period. There is always some explanation about how Internet was invented later; some of them say it was invented when the world‚Äôs population reached a billion, and the first computers also were created.
Michelangelo didn‚Äôt just discover the Internet, he also created the first computer networks so that his enemies

instruction: What if the Black Death had not occurred in the 14th century?
output:
What if the Black Death had not occurred in the 14th century? In this lecture, you will hear how a sudden epidemic could have led to the collapse of the Byzantine or Western Roman Empire long before the rise of the Ottoman Turks. You will also consider why, in the absence of these epidemics, the West went through the Renaissance and the Scientific Revolution even though it lacked literacy.
The Rise of Scientific Knowledge
The first lecture discusses the reasons for the rise of scientific knowledge from its origin on Earth, to the discovery of water on Mars, and the nature of light through history.
Lecture 1: The Rise of Scientific Knowledge
The Renaissance saw a revival of mathematical and scientific pursuits in Europe that helped bring about the modern scientific view of the world. This began with the observation of astronomical phenomena which helped make it possible to determine the shape of the Earth. However, scientific theories are still subject to human nature and beliefs. This lecture will examine such things as scientific revolution, the belief that the Earth is flat, and why these things arose in that era.
Astronomy and the Scientific Method
The second lecture describes how various cultures have used ancient astronomy and mathematics in order to discover new scientific methods. Such discoveries often come about through an examination of the cosmos, and the ability to make sound observations is very useful when it comes to learning about how our world works. The lecture looks at some of the important observations astronomers made, how they were able to figure out new methods of counting and measuring, and the reasons they were able to determine that the Earth is spherical. It concludes by talking about how the scientific method has become a central part of how we understand our world.
Great Discoveries in Modern Physics and Cosmology
The third lecture begins by discussing how Einstein became famous for his new theory of relativity. This lecture discusses physics in the second part of the 20th century, including his ideas, which have since been supported by many others. The cosmological discoveries made in the same time period will also be explored. It examines several new theories, including inflation theory, the cyclic theory of the cosmos, and many others.
The Rise of Modern Science in the 20th Century
The rise of modern science in the 20th century is what was in large part responsible for the economic development of the Western world that led to the "Great Recession" and rise of developing countries all over the world. How did this happen? This is the topic of this lecture. After studying the history of science and the development of technology, it will be concluded that what happened was inevitable. This lecture includes a discussion of the importance of understanding the history of science and the contributions of various people in order to achieve something that is not only beneficial, but also irreversible.
How Did Astronomy Transcend the Dark Ages?
The history of astronomy during the Dark Ages is a fascinating subject. This lecture will talk about how the Roman Empire came to an end and the rise of the Christian religion, and the fact that during this period there was a great advance in astronomy. There was also a large amount of progress made in a very specific way that will be discussed in this lecture. This will focus on how different cultures have changed with the time and how the Romans became the rulers of Western Europe, both before and after the fall of the Roman Empire. The fact that all this happened is important, since there were a lot of changes happening in the world at this time. These changes were significant because they made it possible for a new religion to become so popular, and this religion was Christianity. Although there were many new technologies and inventions during this time, these changed how people lived, and we will discuss these advancements later.
Galileo Galilei and the Birth of Modern Science
Galileo Galilei was a great scientist who made many important discoveries. He is an important part of the story of modern science because he introduced scientific methods to astronomy that we still use today. We will discuss Galileo's scientific discoveries and his use of telescopes to discover Jupiter's four moons and Venus's phases, and how he used scientific theory rather than religion to decide whether or not the Earth orbited the Sun. This also involved his conflict with the Church, of which he was excommunicated for heresy, which will be discussed. For Galileo, science was based on observation, not the Bible, and his legacy lives on.
The Scientific Revolution in the 17th Century
The 17th century was a time of important developments in European thought. A scientific revolution occurred at this time, and it brought about a lot of progress in the study of astronomy and other sciences. In this lecture, we will learn about how this happened and what happened during it. Some important people from this time who made important discoveries will be described as well. These revolutions in science and philosophy were important for the development of the scientific revolution.
Evidence

instruction: What if Isaac Newton had focused on biology instead of physics?
output:
What if Isaac Newton had focused on biology instead of physics?" asked Robert Hazen, director of the Geophysical Laboratory and co-author of a book with Seiffert and a forthcoming one called "Origins: The Quest for Our Cosmic Roots."
"It's conceivable that a few million years of tinkering with these molecules could have led to the origin of life," he said. "I can't see any good reason, though, why the same chemistry that led to life on Earth cannot in fact have occurred on another planet."
Sehifert was one of more than 40 experts to share their views during a conference held earlier this month at George Washington University in Washington. Sponsored by the National Academy of Sciences, many of the participants came from the space sciences, astrobiology, cosmology and planetary science fields. Some noted that it is hard to imagine Mars and Earth being so similar that life could have appeared on the two planets at the same time.
"We don't have the data to say where the 'golden spike' is on Mars, since life may not have appeared there at all," said David Revesz, an astrobiologist with the U.S. Geological Survey's Astrogeology Science Center near Flagstaff, Ariz.
Astrogeologist and geologist-planetary-scientists were also asked to submit questions to the scientific community via e-mail. After reviewing the scientific literature, they said there was no consensus of a "significant and compelling evidence" for life on Mars, although some geoscientists believed that the planet's climate may have been more hospitable to life in the past, with longer, warmer summers and greater precipitation.
Mars could be habitable in its early history, if it was similar to the early Earth, according to a University of Southern California-based Mars rover project manager. By the time the rovers landed, they would have found ancient shorelines, lakes or even swamps, and could then be sent out to determine if they found life, said Jim Garvin, chief scientist of NASA's Mars Exploration Program at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. If Mars looked like our planet about 3 billion years ago, it may have had a thicker atmosphere that allowed oceans to exist and therefore a greater potential for life, he said.
"If we were to find things on Mars that were very similar or identical to biological activity, I would be astounded," he said.
As to the question of whether Mars could someday become Earth, which is known to have undergone a series of devastating asteroid strikes that resulted in mass extinctions, "We are in the beginning of our evolution," he said.
Scientists have speculated that asteroids may have sparked the evolution of life on Earth by delivering bits of microorganisms, microfossils and "mixed-bag molecules" that led to life, said Garvin. The impact was especially important in shaping life, he said, because it was the only type of mass extinction that was caused by something biological.
"Is there a point of no come back?" he asked. "I don't see it yet."

instruction: What if the Beatles had never formed as a band?
output:
What if the Beatles had never formed as a band?!
In that case, I guess we‚Äôd be getting the Yellow Submarine and the White Album from each of them in solo form, along with Magical Mystery Tour and Revolver to round out other projects that didn‚Äôt make it into their own, but overall, it‚Äôs a moot point ‚Ä¶ the Beatles‚Äô influence is forever and they left us with some of the greatest music ever made, and we are all the better for it.
A Bigger Bang
A Bigger Bang (2005)
One more? Yep, we need more Lennon/McCartney/Harrison, so here‚Äôs a bit more of that, and the album is even more varied and diverse than its three predecessors with a smattering of disco, folk, gospel and of course some rock ‚Äòn roll too.
There‚Äôs the funky and slightly disco-ish ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Let Me Down‚Äù backed with the ‚Äúsilly love song,‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Satisfied‚Äù ‚Äì which to our ears sounds like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Happy Just To Dance With You‚Äù by the Beatles. There‚Äôs a lovely gospel-tinged take on ‚ÄúWhat Is Life‚Äù and a gorgeous remake of ‚ÄúMother Nuzzing,‚Äù featuring Paul and Ringo backing John for the first time since ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Down‚Äù from Help! in 1965 (and one of the last Lennon songs he‚Äôd release before his death, on Double Fantasy in 1980).
There‚Äôs a pair of covers with interesting Beatles connections ‚Äì they‚Äôre both by Bob Dylan, first there‚Äôs ‚ÄúMr. Tambourine Man‚Äù which Dylan gave to the Byrds in 1965 at the height of their fame. The Beatles covered the song (and the Byrds!) on the second side of the ‚ÄúRubber Soul‚Äù album. Then they also cover Dylan‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Want You,‚Äù which he released by himself on his 1966 LP, ‚ÄúBlonde on Blonde‚Äù ‚Äì although the Beatles also covered it on The White album in 1968 in a rather sloppy live version.
As the last ‚ÄúSolo Albums,‚Äù A Bigger Bang is kind of a fitting conclusion to a four-album run of music. A Bigger Bang is also the end of the Fab Four‚Äôs classic period, as the breakup and subsequent Beatles breakup is almost inevitable following this album and the dissolution of The Beatles itself was only a couple years away.
The song that best encapsulates the band‚Äôs end is ‚ÄúSomedays,‚Äù which is a ballad where a couple are talking about growing old and losing their youth as they remember the good times they‚Äôve enjoyed, and how things aren‚Äôt as good as they once were. John, Paul and Ringo all contribute vocals, but George is not heard on this song for the first time since ‚ÄúDo You Want To Know A Secret‚Äù in 1963, so the song feels somewhat like it‚Äôs the end for the band itself.
A Bigger Bang is in part a ‚Äúbest of‚Äù compilation, as there are some previously-released tracks: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Let Me Down,‚Äù along with ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Satisfied,‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôve Got A Feeling‚Äù and ‚ÄúTwo Of Us‚Äù (which they had released on the ‚ÄúLet It Be‚Ä¶Naked‚Äù album in 2003). But this is also in part a fresh start without any of the band, and there are many more new songs than we‚Äôre used to. This is also the first album since ‚ÄúMagical Mystery Tour‚Äù where John doesn‚Äôt have the lead vocals on the majority of the tracks, and we have a chance to hear all four of them as solo artists, and while it‚Äôs a mixed bag, there are some gems here. There are a few of my favorite Lennon songs, including ‚ÄúSomedays,‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Satisfied,‚Äù ‚ÄúGoing Down On Love‚Äù and ‚ÄúShe Looks Good To Me‚Äù
This album is a worthy addition to the Lennon/McCartney catalog, which is no small feat, and there is no denying the contribution of each member. A Bigger Bang was produced by Yoko Ono, and while you can hear her influence, there‚Äôs something about this album that‚Äôs just Beatles, and that‚Äôs part of its charm. John, Paul, George and Ringo ‚Äì four different people, but they were never better than when together, and A Bigger Bang captures that perfectly.
John Lennon & Yoko Ono
Lennondisco
More Lennon, we could hardly ask for more, but perhaps only one more album is possible. This one is more obscure ‚Äì Lennon didn‚Äôt contribute to it ‚Äì but it‚Äôs a bit of a Lennon curiosity ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs the second and last album from John and Yoko (

instruction: What if Alan Turing had not cracked the Enigma code during World War II?
output:
What if Alan Turing had not cracked the Enigma code during World War II? You might see Turing as the quintessential mathematician and think of him as more of an abstract abstract theorist than as a man with important contributions to society, but it‚Äôs not like he never did anything in life other than work on codebreaking theory. Turing made huge contributions to computing and artificial intelligence, which are a lot more relevant than codebreaking, and those contributions are now considered essential to much of what‚Äôs going on in our lives today.
In this video, Turing‚Äôs friend and colleague Roger Penrose explains what would have happened if the British had developed computers before the Germans, which may seem like a silly question. He‚Äôs also in a video here talking about Turing‚Äôs contributions in mathematics.
(Also check out Penrose‚Äôs work on quantum mechanics here, and his ideas about the limitations of logic as a basis for physics here .)
(Cross-posted at Rationally Speaking)
Filed Under: Mathematics, Society & Culture Tagged With: Alan Turing, Artificial Intelligence, Computing, Enigma, Enigma Code, Enigma Machine, Mathematics, Physics, Quantum Mechanics, Roger Penrose, World War II

instruction: What if the Suez Canal had never been constructed?
output:
What if the Suez Canal had never been constructed?
If the Suez Canal had never been constructed, it is doubtful that Great Britain would have entered the First World War. In 1914, Great Britain was still the world's largest manufacturer, her fleet was the largest and most technologically advanced in the world, and her navies, army and air force were strong by most standards. However, that strength was dependent upon her global access and the dominance of the British Empire. She would have found it very difficult to wage such a war without control of the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean. Britain's entry into the war hinged largely upon the defeat of the Turks and the opening of the Suez Canal to traffic. After being closed in 1914, the Suez Canal was reopened in February 1915, making travel from Britain easier to India and the Middle East. This improved Britain's strategic position and helped Great Britain secure an alliance with France, a significant step as Britain had previously been reluctant to form such an alliance and had in fact been very wary of a large naval and land force on the continent. The Allies, along with the United States, used this combined effort to counter Germany's successful war efforts in both Europe and Africa.
While there is debate over how much the Suez Canal's construction impacted foreign policy, few doubt it was important, as Britain would not have fought in World War I had the Suez Canal not been built. Likewise, had this canal been destroyed by Germany in its unsuccessful attack on Egypt, it is unlikely that Britain would have fought in World War I. The strategic importance of the Suez Canal cannot be overstated.
Sources: University of Texas at San Antonio
The Suez Canal and the Suez Crisis
The Suez Crisis was a British, French and Israeli attempt in 1956 to oust the Egyptian government. In 1956 Egypt nationalized the Suez Canal under President Nasser. The three nations planned on the canal's resumption to civilian use and control by Western nations. They made an agreement among themselves to stop Egypt's attempts to nationalize Egypt's other assets. Then the British, French, and Israelis invaded Egypt and bombarded Egypt with ships to regain control of the Suez. However, the Russians intervened by blocking the flow of Soviet funds to Israel and, further, the Americans told the British and French about their plan to invade Egypt. Britain and France were forced to back off, and the U. N. helped broker a cease-fire. There was no peace deal, there was no agreement except to stop the violence.
Source: www.fpri.org
If the Suez Canal had never been constructed it is doubtful that Great Britain would have entered World War I as Great Britain was still the world's largest manufacturer, and her fleet was the largest and most technologically advanced in the world, and her navy, army and air force were strong by the standards of most other military forces in the world. However, that strength was highly dependent upon Britain's global presence and the dominance of the British Empire. Had the Suez Canal never been constructed, it is unlikely that Britain would have been involved in World War I as Britain would have found it difficult to wage such a war without control of the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean. After being closed in 1914, the Suez Canal was reopened in February 1915, but this did not change the situation as Britain still needed to have some form of naval presence in the Indian Ocean. The Suez Crisis in 1956 shows that the Suez Canal is essential to the British Empire (and by extension, the American Empire). In the Second World War, the Allied forces were able to defeat Germany and Italy in Europe.
In 1955, when Egypt nationalized the Suez Canal, British and French officials considered the following options:
-to pressure Egypt to reconsider and privatize the canal
-to negotiate with Egypt and Egypt's allies (the United States and the Soviet Union) on this question
-to prepare for war
-to find a peaceful solution to the nationalization of the canal
The first two options were rejected because they could not ensure that the canal would not be nationalized and because the United States would have been more willing to compromise than the Soviet Union. The third option, war, was chosen for two reasons: the perceived need to maintain access to the Mediterranean Sea, and the belief that the war would serve as a diplomatic opening to a "third way" between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. This belief was based on the idea that the Suez Crisis would serve as an example to all nations of their need to abide by the rules of international law, including the United Nations Charter. instruction: What if Christopher Columbus had not discovered the Americas?
output:
What if Christopher Columbus had not discovered the Americas?" was not included because there's more than one Christopher Columbus.
Some say the English didn't "discover" America because they didn't "discover" it for themselves, but that the Vikings came here centuries before and settled North America. The VOC's activities in China and India come into question. If the Dutch East India Company had not been in India, if it hadn't been started in VOC at all, who knows what Indian art would look like today. Would America be more European-looking, or would it look more African or Asian?
What if? What if? What if? What if? What if? What if? What if? What if? What if? What if?
I was very pleased when it was decided to open a branch of the museum and display a collection of paintings, including Rembrandt's "The Jewish Bride," so beloved to the VOC.
The VOC Art Collection was created as early as 1620, and was to be considered a separate entity from the company.
And so, the VOC Art Collection was also called the Rembrandt Collection, although Rembrandt wasn't a member, not even a shareholder. All he did was paint a picture for the Amsterdam chapter -- a portrait of Johannes Michiel, the Grand Treasurer -- and this painting later became known simply as "The VOC."
Many other pictures by Rembrandt were to be bought or donated. For example, the VOC bought, from the heirs of his son, the portrait of Willem van de Velde. And after Rembrandt's death, his wife asked for help from the art lover Michiel and even offered to paint a portrait of him in exchange for some of his paintings. Her proposal was made for 12 large paintings, but because she's an artist herself, she knew it didn't make sense to make a portrait of someone that has passed away. A painting of a person still alive is a portrait of the living person, but a painting of someone that has passed away is a memorial, a painting with a meaning. On a painting of her, Rembrandt painted her son Titus.
And so, when Michiel asked, "What do you want?" she responded,
"I want The Jewish Bride. I have a letter saying that Rembrandt will give it to me if I need it" -- referring to Michiel's request to Rembrandt, asking if The Jewish Bride will remain with the VOC after Rembrandt's own death.
He said he would.
Rembrandt was known to be in good company, having received help from Michiel many times, and Michiel was known for collecting art. Because Rembrandt was dead by then, the VOC was asked to take responsibility for The Jewish Bride; it would be given to another art lover, another company, another country... as Rembrandt himself had wanted it to be.
On March 15th, 2017, that's exactly how it happened: it was auctioned; it was sold and then it was sent to the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.
It was sold for 6.84 million euros.
We didn't get to see it, it's locked up in a safe.
The museum will not be displaying Rembrandt's most famous painting, but perhaps it will be better for The Rijks to have it.
The VOC had more than The Rembrandt Collection, but only that collection was mentioned by name. The other collection (the Rembrandt Collection) was officially called the VOC Art Collection, a collection with 54 paintings, all by Rembrandt, including the original portrait of his son Titus, who became the "living" person, and who had been added as a posthumous character to The Jewish Bride (his picture was in it also) to complete Rembrandt's intended meaning.
It was the first Dutch art collection.
On a previous blog post, I mentioned how The Rijksmuseum got its name from a former inn, the Rijkershuys, which had a private art collection; the collection consisted of 224 paintings acquired by the wealthy burgomaster Jacob de Rijcke, and which he left to the city at the time of his death, and which have remained there ever since. The VOC Art Collection was part of The Rijksmuseum's founding, as was the painting of Jacob de Rijcke's painting collection (pictured at the top).
This painting "has historical merit," and so a small exhibition about it has been opened, showing it as part of the museum for the first time in decades. I was very pleased!

instruction: What if Vincent van Gogh had been a successful artist during his lifetime?
output:
What if Vincent van Gogh had been a successful artist during his lifetime?
The French painter and sculptor Auguste Rodin made this prediction to his friend Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec early in the twentieth century. At the time, Toulouse-Lautrec was attempting to help van Gogh, a painter with whom he shared a turbulent friendship, with the last works and letters before his suicide. Rodin‚Äôs prediction foretelling of the subsequent success of van Gogh‚Äôs work was not completely untrue: after his death, his art and reputation grew. And yet Toulouse-Lautrec had told Rodin the same thing after meeting van Gogh in Paris. The two had become friends through Toulouse-Lautrec‚Äôs connection with Edgar Degas, another French painter. But as Toulouse-Lautrec and van Gogh began to paint together, the young artist started to criticize Degas‚Äô style.
Auguste Rodin, Portrait of Vincent van Gogh (c. 1912).
The last time Toulouse-Lautrec saw van Gogh, the younger artist was about to take his own life. There was a sense of hopelessness at this time for van Gogh, as his last works and letters would make clear. Van Gogh, who struggled to make a living as an art dealer, had been unable to develop the skills he needed to sell his work. It is this that led him to an attempt on his own life, although most historians have concluded that the attack was the result of the mental illness (then known as epilepsy) that he would suffer most of his life.[1]
Rodin wrote to Toulouse-Lautrec, suggesting that a successful showing of van Gogh‚Äôs work in Paris might save him from committing suicide. After Toulouse-Lautrec returned and reported on the show, no longer wanting to paint, Rodin‚Äôs prediction came true.
The show featured roughly six hundred works by van Gogh, who painted them in his last fifteen months of life. Toulouse-Lautrec was not sure whether to report on the display, fearing it would bring unwanted attention to van Gogh. In his autobiography, L‚Äôargent et la gloire (Money and Fame), Toulouse-Lautrec recalls asking his mother for her opinion on the matter:
Mon p√®re pensait que mon oncle n‚Äôavait plus la force de travailler, et que sa seule t√¢che √©tait de passer son temps √† d√©charger au plus haut point les derni√®res ann√©es de sa vie. S‚Äôil vivait encore longtemps et reprenait, ainsi, quelques ann√©es de jeunesse, cela pouvait lui servir. Mon parrain, qui √©tait un p√¢tre et n‚Äôen avait pas plus de sept ans, lui ayant demand√© si il avait fait, depuis son retour √† Aix, un peu de dessins ou de peintures, avait reu une r√©tribution d√©cevante. ‚Äî Peindrez-vous encore, mon cher ami, lui avait demand√© le chevalier, vous √™tes tr√®s bon dessinateur √† l‚Äô≈ìuvre. ‚Äî Peindre, lui avait r√©pondu mon parrain, oui, comme mon parrain d‚Äôautrefois, j‚Äôai la tendance √† peindre. Il allait laisser d‚Äôautres le soin de cette chose.
‚ÄúMy father thought that my uncle could no longer work and that his only task in life was to spend the last years of his life doing nothing. If he lived on, he might gain some more years of youth. My godfather, who was an artist and had already been in the business for less than seven years, gave him a fee that was disappointing. ‚ÄòDo you continue to paint, dear friend,‚Äô he asked him, ‚Äòyou are doing very good drawings at work.‚Äô ‚ÄòI will paint,‚Äô my godfather had answered, ‚Äòjust like my godfather of old times, I have a tendency to paint. I leave it to other people to do the work.‚Äô‚Äù[2]
Auguste Rodin, Van Gogh's Mother and Sister at Amsterdam (c. 1912).
The show was held in 1912 at the Galerie Bernheim-Jeune in Paris. During the next few months, van Gogh sold roughly 2,700 paintings via 97 different sales.[3] In the last six months of his life, van Gogh generated about a quarter of his total income from those works alone. The show also included fifty of his most recent letters to Theo,

output:
Implement a Python function to find the longest common subsequence of two input strings using dynamic programming.  Do not print redundant characters.
def longest_common_subsequence(s1, s2):
    s1_len = len(s1)
    s2_len = len(s2)
    L = [[0]*s2_len for i in range(0, s1_len+1)]
    result = []
    for i in range(0,s2_len+1):
        L[0][i] = 0
        for j in range(1,s1_len+1):
            L[j][i] = max(L[j-1][i], s1[j-1] == s2[i-1]?L[j-1][i-1]+1:0)
            L[j][i] = max(L[j][i], L[j-1][i])
        result.append(L[s1_len][s2_len])
    return result
    
s1 = 'abcdaeffdggh'
s2 = 'daeffdggh'
print( longest_common_subsequence(s1, s2))

Python: Finding all permutations of string
import string
def find_all_perm(s):
    # Create a string of all possible characters of the string to be permuted
    length = len(string.ascii_lowercase)-1
    cs = [i for i in range(length)]
    res = []
    # Find all possible permutations of string
    for i in range(1,length+2):
        for j in range(0,length+i):
            res.append(cs[:j]+s.split()[i:j]+cs[j:])
    return res         
     
s = 'abcdefg'
print(find_all_perm(s))

s = 'asdfj'
print(find_all_perm(s[:5]))

instruction: Implement a regular expression in Python to validate an email address.
output:
Implement a regular expression in Python to validate an email address. A regular expression used to validate an Email ID are as follows:

  * `[a-zA-Z]`: This identifies a letter

  * `[0-9]`: This identifies a number

  * `@`: This identifies the @ symbol

  * `.`: This identifies a period or any character

  * `.*\.`: This identifies a period followed by any alphanumeric value

**Result** : The following code snippet shows an example of validating an email address using the regular expression mentioned at the beginning.

    import re

    re.search(r"(^[a-zA-Z]{3,25}@[a-zA-Z]{3,12})+$", "gmail@gmail.com")

Output:

A regular expression is generally written from the right-hand side towards the left-hand side. This is because the part to be interpreted first must be located at the left-hand side of the expression.

# Nested loops

In Python, you can use a standard for loop to iterate through the values of one data structure for a particular period of time. In many cases, it might be good to loop over all the elements of the second list after executing the loop over the value of the first list. It is good to separate the second list into several rows based on the number of elements of the first list. The following code and diagram shows you how you can do this:

**Code** : Let's declare two lists, `student_list` and `marks_list`, both are of the type `List[int]`. Let them get initialized with the following code:

  * student_list = list()

  * marks_list = list()

  * student_list.append(1)

  * student_list.append(2)

  * student_list.append(3)

In this case, the first element of the marks list is initialized with 0, so the following code will be executed:

  * marks_list.append(0)

Now, let's add the second list to the first list, and the following code will be executed:

  * for ele in student_list:

  *     marks_list.append(1)

In this part, both lists are read and processed in parallel. In this case, both lists are filled with the value `1`, as shown here:

    1 2 3 0

Also, the following statement will be executed:

    marks_list.append(2)

When the for loop is processed, each item is read and the corresponding value of the item is stored as a list at the same time using `marks_list` as shown here:

    1 2 3 0 2 

If you add `4`, it will be a little bit different from the preceding values. You will get the following result:

    4 1 2 3 0 2 4  

So, it is clear to see that the `marks_list` is filled with the value `1` three times and `2` three times. Also, the value `4` has been added twice. If you want to loop over all the data in the `marks_list` then the following code will do the following:

  * for each_marks in marks_list:

  *     print(each_marks)

The last statement will print the list in pairs as shown here:

    0

    1

    2

    3

    4 

    1 

    2 

    3

    4

Now, if you want to have nested for loops, then the following code will help you:

    **for student_index in student_list:**

    **print("Student: " + str(student_list[student_index]))**

    **for each_mark in marks_list:**

    **if each_mark == 0:**

    **continue**

    **elif each_mark == 1:**

    **print("Marks: " + "1")**

    **elif each_mark == 2:**

    **print("Marks: " + "2")**

    **else:**

    **print("Marks: " + "3")**

# Write a python program to reverse a string


#Programming Problems 1

# The following code will take in a string and print a reverse version of it. 
# It does this by creating a new list, and adding the characters to 
# it in reverse order. The characters are turned into a list and the size is
# returned which gives an easy way to check if the string was reversed
def reverse_string(string):
    new_list = []
    for i in string:
        new_list.append(i)
    size = len(new_list)
    return new_list, size

string_input = input('Please, enter a string: ')
new_string, string_input_reverse = reverse_string(string_input)
print(f'String of {len(new_string)} characters and the reversed version is: {new_string}')

#Programming Problems 2

#The following code allows you to take three integer numbers and calculate 
#the number of times you have to add them that their sum adds up to 3,4,
#5, .... and to a certain number (default 100 or the user specified).
# The number of times you need to add them to get to a certain sum. 
#Example, 3,4,5, you get to the sum of 12 by adding the two smallest
#numbers 3 and 4 once, and the third number 5 twice. This method works by 
#keeping track of the numbers in a list and adding them with 
#the add_numbers. This class also gives you a print of these numbers.
class AddToSum:
    def __init__(self, number_list: list, sum_to_add: int):
        self.number_list = number_list
        self.sum_to_add = sum_to_add
        self.calculation_index = len(number_list)
        self.is_done = False

    def add_numbers(self,number_to_add) -> list:
        if self.calculation_index > 0:
            remaining_numbers = self.number_list[1:]
            remaining_numbers.insert(0, number_to_add)
            self.calculation_index += 1
            self.number_list = list(remaining_numbers)

        if self.sum_to_add > 0:
            self.calculation_index += 1
        elif len(self.number_list) == 1 and self.sum_to_add == 0:
            self.is_done = True

    def get_answer(self) -> int:
        return self.calculation_index

num_list = [1, 1, 2, 13]
add_num = AddToSum(num_list, 10)
add_num.add_numbers(3)
print(f'Addition_to_sum: {add_num.get_answer()}')

instruction: Can you help me write a resignation letter to my current employer, while leaving on good terms and expressing gratitude for the opportunities provided?
output:
Can you help me write a resignation letter to my current employer, while leaving on good terms and expressing gratitude for the opportunities provided? I‚Äôd like to thank him, by name, for the help, help he has offered me to improve myself and for the new position he helped get me into at this company.
I feel so confident and inspired by how great this place has been for me. The work has been so interesting and meaningful, and I am so proud of how my skills have grown. I‚Äôve felt like I have grown so much over this year and the company has been a big part of that. I‚Äôm very grateful for all the opportunities I‚Äôve had and the things I‚Äôve learned.
You‚Äôre currently only a month into your first year at a new position here. Do you regret that you‚Äôre looking to leave early?
While I‚Äôve really enjoyed my first month at all of the new things I‚Äôve been doing, I find myself beginning to get burnt out and feel like I want a break. A break for me means time with family and spending time with friends. I feel like this will give me a lot of perspective on my life and how much I really love spending time with people I want to be around the most.
How long do you intend to take?
I‚Äôd like to take a week or two, but I‚Äôm willing and open to taking a little more.
You really appreciate this opportunity. This move has pushed you in your career in ways none of us anticipated. It‚Äôs certainly had significant impact on you on the personal level as well, although you don‚Äôt explicitly address that?
Yes, being in a new city, and new to the company, working amongst people from more than 10 different countries gave me a great perspective on what it is that we call home. Our homes, our place to live, are so important. Home can also be a place like this.
Is it a company I could see myself in a similar position in, in three years?
At some point I would like to move away from the consulting and into more in-house work. This opportunity has given me the confidence and training to help. So I hope you can find someone here that I can mentor as well or work here long enough to feel confident that I‚Äôll have the experience and skills to be able do so further in the future.
Is there more we have covered that you think needs to be said?
I want to make sure the people who worked with me know I would consider myself a good employee. I try to get the job done and do what is asked of me professionally and that has always come through with me at all jobs I‚Äôve had. I hope to never bring my employers, any of them, to task. Thank you for supporting me through my career.
You would like to be in a position to go back?
For the next year or so, I‚Äôd like to continue working here. I still really enjoy the work and, although I‚Äôm ready for a rest, I‚Äôm not actively looking to find myself in a new position.
Will you miss this client?
Absolutely! I would be so sad if I didn‚Äôt get to continue working with them and see what more they will be doing in the future.
Are there any other issues you‚Äôd like to discuss with me?
Are you asking me about this resignation letter and the future?
Can we schedule this?
There is a lot to contemplate and discuss that you have presented to me today. I feel an obligation to be an honest listener to you and help you with what you want.
Do you mind if I ask you a few questions?
No. I‚Äôd be very interested to hear how you will help me with my problem?
Are you willing to discuss something of a more personal nature with me?
How far are you from this letter going to go?
Are you interested in helping me find a job? I‚Äôd like to help my wife and my family.
Would you like me to help you find a job?
Yes. The problem is, I need to find a job. I‚Äôm burnt out. I need a job that will give me more than just money, I want something that will give me a sense of purpose.
Is there anything more you would like to discuss with me? No, that‚Äôs everything I would be willing to discuss.
Are you willing to discuss something of a more personal nature with me, such as my wife or my family?
It‚Äôs just that when I told them I was looking to leave work early they said I should talk to my wife. I thought this was something I should talk to you about first?
I‚Äôm sorry to hear this. Is there anything I can do?
I think I owe them an explanation why I‚Äôm looking to leave work early.
Would you like to tell me

Write a thank-you email to customers who leave positive reviews on your website or on Google.
Customize subject lines. Different emails require different subject lines to persuade recipients to open and read your emails. For example, when sending a reminder email to boost sales, a subject line like, ‚ÄúI need your help!‚Äù would grab the recipient‚Äôs attention while a more formal subject like, ‚ÄúInquiry regarding Item 3073‚Äù would not. On the other hand, a subject line in your follow-up email, like, ‚ÄúThanks for your purchase last week‚Äù would make perfect sense. You get the point.
The best approach to writing email subject lines is to consider the action the recipient is taking. For example, if you already know you have a customer who is very loyal you may choose to address that customer‚Äôs name in the subject of the email. If you‚Äôre sending an email to someone you‚Äôve never met before, your subject could be written as a question instead.
Create a list and put your customers into categories. If you have multiple emails to send out, try to create a list of your customers who fall into certain categories. Instead of trying to customize emails to fit each of your 40 customers, you can create several categories and send emails to every email recipient who meets the defined criteria. This not only saves you time but also makes your emails look more tailored since you‚Äôre appealing to specific demographics that are more likely to convert.
Send email updates based on customer needs. Are you getting frequent questions from customers about how to find you on your website? If so, you can send a customer a customized set of answers that include your website‚Äôs address and the steps they can take to get to you on the website. If you‚Äôre a jewelry designer you can also send your customers who are looking for rings a link to your ring-related articles. This will help you set yourself apart from other business‚Äôs that don‚Äôt offer this type of service.
Provide a link to your product catalogue. In addition to making it easy for your customers to find you on your website, it‚Äôs important that you make it easy for your customers to browse your product catalogue with a quick click of their mouse or a swipe of their phone. This will also improve your SEO since it‚Äôs a highly optimized landing page for your website.
Use your emails to send your customers a special code that they can use on your website or mobile app. The point of these codes is to make it easier for customers to purchase what they want. If a customer is looking to buy an item or accessories from a particular country, sending them a code that they can enter on your site, they will be more likely to purchase. instruction: Structure a podcast script for an episode discussing the influence of streaming platforms on the music industry.
output:
Structure a podcast script for an episode discussing the influence of streaming platforms on the music industry.
Analyze and evaluate existing media (for example, podcasts, articles, music reviews, fan forums, etc.) to analyze their impact on the genre(s) your podcast covers.
Review existing data and research
For existing data and research, you may want to start by examining:
The role of streaming in the music industry
The use of Spotify‚Äôs podcasts
The impact of streaming on radio formats
The impact of streaming on radio format demographics
The effect of podcasts on radio formats
The effect of streaming on music
The effect of streaming on music demographics
How does streaming impact the music industry?
Streaming has become the dominant force in the music industry, with millions of listeners spending hours each week streaming their favorite artists.
This has led to a rise in streaming-only artists, such as Drake and Kanye West, who have become household names.
While streaming has revolutionized the industry, it has also had a negative impact on the economy.
For instance, streaming has caused album sales to plummet, making it harder for older artists to make a living.
Consequently, many musicians have resorted to becoming podcast hosts to make some more money.
Additionally, streaming has made it easier to steal music, which has led to an increase in piracy.
Finally, streaming has led to increased competition among artists, who must now compete for attention on an increasingly crowded platform.
The role of Spotify‚Äôs podcasts
When Spotify launched its podcasts, they hoped that it would become the dominant platform for audio content.
The company has invested heavily in expanding its podcast library, and its platform now includes over 70,000 shows.
However, the company has come under fire from many in the music industry for not properly protecting musicians who stream their content on the platform.
Some musicians feel that Spotify is not doing enough to compensate them for their work, and they have taken to streaming their music without permission of the artist.
In addition, there are worries that Spotify may be monopolizing the podcast market, and will end up leaving many artists out of pocket.
Ultimately, Spotify‚Äôs podcast platform is a mixed bag for musicians.
It has the potential to be a great marketplace for musicians, but it is also possible for the company to end up monopolizing the market and leaving many artists out of pocket.
The use of Spotify‚Äôs podcasts
For years, popular podcasts have aired on stations across the country.
These shows have attracted legions of fans, who tune in to hear their favorite hosts talk about everything from pop culture to politics.
But in recent years, podcast producers have been finding new ways to reach their audiences.
One way has been to create exclusive content for streaming platforms like Spotify.
This new content has the potential to change the way people listen to podcasts, and it could also help boost ratings for popular shows.
The impact of streaming on radio format demographics
A recent analysis has found that streaming music services such as Spotify, Apple Music and Netflix are increasingly leading to a declining number of teenagers and young adults tuning into traditional radio.
According to the research, listeners aged 14-24 are the least likely to stream music due to a lack of awareness of streaming services and the inability to use a smartphone or computer to listen.
While radio stations are still highly successful among this demographic, they are no longer being used as frequently by younger audiences.
This could have significant ramifications for the future of radio in addition to being a loss in ad revenue.
The effect of podcasts on radio formats
For years, the radio format has been the most popular form of media for listeners.
However, in recent years, streaming services have begun to gain in popularity, and some listeners are saying goodbye to traditional radio.
This shift has caused a dramatic drop in ratings for some traditional radio formats, such as news and talk shows.
What does it mean for traditional radio formats?
There are several factors that are contributing to this decline in ratings, and it‚Äôs not clear what the long-term consequences will be.
If traditional radio formats are unable to compete with streaming services, it could mean the end of some of the most popular radio shows
The effect of streaming on music
Streaming music has been a controversial topic ever since its introduction.
Some claim that it helps artists increase their audience, while others argue that it‚Äôs leading to copyright infringement and a decline in music sales.
No matter what side you‚Äôre on, there is no denying that streaming music is rapidly changing the way music is consumed.
How has streaming music affected the music economy?
The debate over streaming music‚Äôs effect on the music economy has been around for years, and there is no doubt that it has had an impact.
